TOU.description: Alabama Power offers numerous time-of-use rates which provide predictable utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer. On-peak hours are defined as 12-7 P.M. from June 1 to September 30 (though some rates define on-peak hours as 1-7 P.M.) and weekdays from 5-9 A.M. from November 1 to March 31. Intermediate-period hours are from 10 A.M. to 12 P.M. and 7 to 9 P.M., Monday to Friday. All other hours are off-peak.

Alabama Power's commercial and industrial customers can enroll in the Business Electric Vehicle Time-of-Use (BEVT) rate and save on energy costs by shifting the charging of electric vehicles (EV) to off-peak (9 P.M.-7 A.M. Monday-Friday from June 1 to September 30) or intermediate (10 A.M. - 12 P.M. and 7 P.M.-9 P.M Monday-Friday from June 1 to September 30 and 7:00 A.M.- 9:00 P.M. Monday-Friday from October 1 - May 31). Peak hours are 12 noon-7 p.m., Monday-Friday, June 1-September 30. Customers under this rate must have their EV charging load metered separately from all other electrical loads. Customers are charged 22.93¢/kWh during on-peak hours and 9.63¢/kWh during off-peak hours.

Arizona Public Service Company (APS) offers time-of-use rates for commercial customers of all sizes. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer months of May-October. Energy charges are highest during on-peak hours between 3 and 8 P.M. on weekdays. These rates also include a demand charge for associated with the 15-minute period of highest demand during the month.

Salt River Project (SRP) offers time-of-use rates for commercial customers. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use from the higher-priced on-peak hours (weekdays 5-9 A.M. during winter 2-7 P.M. during summer) and to the lower-priced off-peak and shoulder hours. Summer periods are May-June and September-October. Prices are highest during the summer peak period of July-August. Customers can try TOU rates for 90 days and, if their first bills are more than they would have paid on the previous rate, they may switch back and will be credited the difference.

Tucson Electric Power (TEP) offers a number of time-of-use rates for commercial customers, allowing them to save energy costs by shifting their energy usage to off-peak periods. Energy charges are higher during the summer (May to September) on-peak hours of 2-8 P.M. and winter on-peak hours of 6-10 A.M. and 5-9 P.M. Weekends and major holidays are considered off-peak hours in both seasons.

The Large General Service Time-of-Use Rate Schedule (GST) from Entergy Arkansas is for customers with demand of less than 1,000 kW. This rate provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months. Summer on-peak hours are defined as June – September weekdays, 1-8 P.M. On-peak hours in other months are from 7 A.M.-6 P.M. Contact Entergy at (800) 368-3749 for more information.

The Large Power Service Time-of-Use Rate Schedule (PST) from Entergy Arkansas is for customers with demand of 1,000 kW and greater. This rate provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months. Summer on-peak hours are defined as June – September weekdays, 1 – 8 P.M. On-peak hours in other months are from 7 A.M.-6 P.M. Contact Entergy at (800) 368-3749 for more information.

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company (OG&E) offers customers time-of-use (TOU) rates that incentivize them to shift their energy demand away from peak hours (weekdays 2-7pm from June to September, excluding company-observed holidays) and save on energy costs. These include the General Service Time-Of-Use Rate for customers with annual energy consumption of less than 140,000 kWh, or maximum demand less than 30kW in the last 12 months, and the Power and Light Time-Of-Use Rate for customers that consumed more than 140,000 kWh of energy and reached a maximum load of at least 30 kW during the past year. Customer and energy charges vary depending on the rate.

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company's (OG&E's) SmartHours program offers a time-of-use (TOU) rate that enables lower total electricity costs for facilities that are able to reduce usage during peak hours (2-7 P.M. weekdays, June 1 through September 30, excluding company-observed holidays) or shift load to off-peak hours, when the rate is substantially lower.

The Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company (OG&E) SmartHours Overnight is an Electric Vehicle time-of-use rate that allows customers to save on energy costs by shifting the charging of electric vehicles away from on-peak hours (2-7 P.M. weekdays excluding company-observed holidays) to when prices are lowest at night.

TOU.hidden_program_name: Lighting and Power - Time of use
TOU.description: Industrial customers of Southwestern Electric Power Company (SWEPCO) who qualify for service under the Lighting and Power Service schedule with a minimum demand of 100 kW can enroll in the Lighting and Power – Time of Use rate to reduce their energy costs by shifting demand away from on-peak hours, which occur non-holiday weekdays between 1 and 7 P.M. from July through September. Customers on both primary and secondary services pay different kW and kWh rates for on-peak and off-peak hours.

Glendale Water and Power offers time-of-use pricing for its small, medium and large business customers. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer. On-peak hours are 2 P.M. to 8 P.M., Monday - Friday, from July through October and 12 P.M. to 9 P.M., Monday-Friday, from November to June. The savings can be substantial. Large business energy charges during off-peak hours of the July-October period are close to a third of energy charges during on-peak hours ($0.1322 vs.
$0.3718).

Pacific Gas and Electric (PG&E) offers two electric vehicle rate plans (BEV1 and BEV2) for business customers with on-site EV charging. Both plans combine a customizable monthly subscription charge with a time-of-use rate. When charging during off-peak (9 P.M. – 9 A.M. and 2– 4 P.M) and "super off-peak" (9 A.M. – 2 P.M) hours customers are offered a lower rate than when charging during peak times (4 -9 P.M.).

PG&E's Base Interruptible Program (BIP) pays participants to reduce electric load to (or below) a level pre-selected by the customer (called the firm service level or FSL) that is below its historic average maximum demand. Customers receive a monthly incentive payment or credit based on the size of the curtailable portion of their load, in return for committing to reduce to the FSL when called upon by the utility with at least 30 minutes' notice. The incentives are up to $13.50 per committed kW per month, even if no events are called. There is a minimum curtailment commitment of 100 kW, or 15% of the monthly average peak demand (whichever is larger). Customers are also required to take service under a time-of-use (TOU) or real-time pricing (RTP) rate to be eligible for this program. Requests for curtailments (which can last up to six hours) cannot exceed one per day, ten per month, or 180 hours per year. Participants are penalized a $6.00/kWh for energy usage over their FSL during a curtailment event. PG&E has contracted with numerous third-party aggregators (also known as curtailment service providers, CSPs) who recruit customers to participate in BIP and manage their participation process. By serving as an intermediary, the aggregators can handle many of the details on the customers' behalf and help them develop load reduction strategies. The aggregators may also offer innovative program features – for example, by assuming the risk of non-compliance penalties or by allowing customers to participate who might otherwise be too small to enroll directly in the utility's program. BIP participants are also eligible for simultaneously participating in other load management opportunities offered by the utility, which allows customers to take advantage of rate credits, reduced energy charges, and incentives associated with both programs, with some restrictions.

PG&E offers numerous times of use rates for commercial customers in California. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use away from on-peak hours (4 to 9 P.M.), particularly during the summer (June through September).

Southern California Edison (SCE) offers three time-of-use Electric Vehicle Rates plans for business customers that separately meter the charging of their electric vehicles. Three rates are offered depending on customer charging demands. Customers pay lower rates when charging during off-peak and "super off-peak" hours. Summer (June 1-September 30) off-peak hours are from 9 to – 4 P.M. (19 hours) and winter (October 1 – May 31) off-peak hours are from 9 P.M. – 8 A.M. with super off-peak hours from 8 A.M. – 4 P.M.

The Base Interruptible Program (BIP) offered by SCE pays participants to reduce electric load to (or below) a level pre-selected by the customer (called the firm service level or FSL) that is below its historic average maximum demand. Customers receive a monthly incentive payment or credit based on the size of the curtailable portion of their load, in return for committing to reduce to the FSL when called upon by the utility with 15-30 minutes' notice, depending on the utility. The incentives are up to $26.11 per committed kW per month, even if no events are called. There is a minimum curtailment commitment of 100 kW, or 15% of the monthly average peak demand (whichever is larger). Customers are also required to take service under a time-of-use (TOU) or real-time pricing (RTP) rate to be eligible for this program. Requests for curtailments (which can last up to six hours) cannot exceed one per day, ten per month, or 180 hours per year. Penalties apply for customers that fail to reduce load as requested. SCE contracted with numerous third-party aggregators (also known as curtailment service providers, CSPs) who recruit customers to participate in BIP and manage their participation process. By serving as an intermediary, the aggregators can handle many of the details on the customers' behalf and help them develop load reduction strategies. The aggregators may also offer innovative program features – for example, by assuming the risk of non-compliance penalties or by allowing customers to participate who might otherwise be too small to enroll directly in the utility's program. BIP participants are also eligible for simultaneously participating in other load management opportunities offered by the utilitie, which allows customers to take advantage of rate credits, reduced energy charges, and incentives associated with both programs, with some restrictions.

SCE provide time-of-use rates for commercial customers. These rates provide utility bill savings who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer (June through September). Business on-peak hours are 4 to 9 P.M. and agriculture & pumping optional on-peak hours are 5 to 8 P.M.

SCE's Critical Peak Pricing (CPP) is a time-of-use rate structure that offers lower electricity rates year-round in return for agreeing to a higher rate during CPP events. Energy used during a CPP event is charged at a higher rate for the duration of the event. Events are called up to 15 times per year and can be called year round, although they usually occur during hot summer days, any day of the week from 4 to 9 P.M. Customers are notified via email or text the day before the event is called. CPP is the default rate for small, medium, and large commercial and industrial customers as well as large agricultural and pumping customers of SCE. For new program entrants, a bill protection option is available that prevents participants from paying more than they would have under their previous rate during the first year of CPP participations.

San Diego Gas and Electric (SDG&E) offers an Electric Vehicle-High Power (EV-HP) rate to its commercial and industrial customers, designed to eliminate unpredictable demand charges by offering lower rates and bill stability through fixed monthly subscription charges. This rate  uses time-of-use energy charges based on when the customer charges their electric vehicle(s), with a steep price differential between times of moderate and heavy demand to motivate fleet owners to charge at times of low demand (off-peak periods). Energy charges are separated out into peak (daily 4 P.M. - 9 P.M.), off-peak (M-F: 6 A.M.- 4 P.M. and 9 P.M - 12 A.M; weekends and holidays 2PM - 4PM and 9 P.M. - 12 A.M.) , and "super off-peak" (M-F: 12 A.M. - 6 A.M. and 10 A.M. - 2 P.M. March and April Only; weekends and holidays: 12 A.M. - 2 P.M.) SDG&E says customers on the EV-HP rate can save as much as %50 on fuel costs compared to diesel.

SDG&E offers numerous time-of-use rates for its commercial customers. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use away from on-peak hours (4 to 9 P.M.), particularly during the summer (June through September).

SDG&E's Critical Peak Pricing Program (CPP) is a time-of-use rate structure that offers lower electricity rates year-round in return for agreeing to a higher rate during CPP events. Energy used during a CPP event is charged at a higher rate for the duration of the event. Events are called up to 18 times per year and can be called year round, although they usually occur during hot summer days, any day of the week from 4 to 9 P.M. Customers are notified via email or text by 3 P.M. the day before the event is called. For new program entrants, a bill protection option is available that prevents participants from paying more than they would have under their previous rate during the first year of CPP participations.

Colorado Springs Utilities offers a time-of-use rate to its commercial customers whose daily use averages less than 1,000 kWh/day in the last 12 billing periods. Savings are available to customers who can shift load away from peak times (11 A.M.–6 P.M. April to September and 4-10 P.M., October through March).

Fort Collins Utilities (FCU) provides time-of-use rates for large commercial and industrial customers to encourage consumption during off-peak periods, especially during the hours when facility and overall grid peaks coincide. The utility provides a Load Management Tool to commercial and industrial customers to notify them of the coincident peak. The Load Management Tool enables customers to track the demand of FCU's wholesale power supplier, Platte River Power Authority. Customers can sign up to receive an email during potential peak hours indicating when to shed load. It is difficult to predict when the peak hour of the month will occur, so FCU identifies about 10 potential peak hours per month. Customers on these rates are assessed a coincident peak demand charge of roughly $16/kW in summer months and $12-$13/kW during non-summer months, compared to $10-$11/kW during non-peak hours, for a peak/non-peak difference of about 25%-50%..

United Illuminating maintains several time-of-use rates. Customers on these rates can saving money by shifting their electricity consumption to off-peak periods ( 8 PM - 12 PM weekdays, and all weekend hours).

Duke Energy (Duke) offers time-of-use rates to its commercial and industrial customers. On-peak periods for TOU rates occur on non-holiday weekdays from 6 to 9 P.M. for all calendar months, as well as 5 to 10 A.M. from December through February.

Florida Power and Light (FPL) offers a variety of time-of-use rates to customers that can shift their demand away from on-peak hours during the summer (April through October) from 12 to 9 P.M. and during the winter (November through March) from 6 to 10 A.M. and 6 to 10 P.M., excluding certain holidays. Time-of-use rates are available annually or seasonally. These include the General Service Demand Time of Use (GSDT) rate for customers whose demand ranges from 25-499 kW (GSDT-1), 500-1999 kW (GSLDT-1), and 2000+ kW (GSLDT-2). Customers with a demand of less than 25 kW are eligible for the General Service - Non Demand - Time of Use Rate (GST-1). These rates are available for all areas served by the utility.

Tampa Electric (TECO) offers time-of-use rates for customers that can shift their demand away from on-peak hours during the summer (April through October), 12 to 9 P.M., and winter (November through March), 6 to 10 A.M. and 6 to 10 P.M. The Time-of-Day Service is available for business customers. Optional Time-of-Day rates are also available for large commercial and industrial customers. For more information or to sign up, call (866) 832-6249 or email mybusinessacount@tecoenergy.com.

Georgia Power offers multiple time-of-use rate options to non-residential customers in Georgia, including food & drink and an electric vehicle charging time of use rate for non-residential premises dedicated to electric vehicle charging. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months. On-peak periods are defined as 2 to 7 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays during the summer (June through September). The Time-of-Use General Service Demand schedule additionally defines a shoulder period as 12-2pm and 7-9pm on non-holiday summer weekdays where energy charges are between those for the on and off peak periods.

Hawaiian Electric is offering a new time-of-use (TOU) rate through a one year pilot program called Shift and Save. The program incentivizes shifting energy use to mid-day hours (when grid power from solar PV installations is plentiful).   There is a 6-month cap for commercial customers that will ensure they see no more than a 4% increase compared to what would have been charged on the existing rate for the same month.

Idaho Power offers a number of time of use rates that allow business customers to save money by shifting energy use from on-peak hours, which have higher prices, to mid- or off-peak hours, which have lower prices. During the summer months, on-peak hours (which occur Monday-Saturday excluding holidays) are 7-11 P.M. For the non-summer period, on-peak hours are 6-9 A.M. and 5-8 P.M. The summer season runs from June-September each year. These rates are available for customers with a metered energy use per billing period greater than 2,000 kWh (Schedule 9) or metered demand per billing period greater than 1,000 kW (Schedule 19).

MidAmerican Energy offers time-of-use rate options to its non-residential customers which allow them to save money by shifting their energy usage away from peak hours (1 to 6 P.M.), weekdays from June through September, to off-peak hours (10 P.M. to 8 A.M.).

Indiana Michigan Power (an AEP company) offers several time-of-day options to its commercial and industrial customers. Customers can save costs by shifitng energy use to times with lower prices. These rates include the General Service Time-of-Day (currently closed) and Large General Service Time-of-Day, which have higher prices during on-peak hours (weekdays 7 A.M.-9 P.M.) compared to other hours. The utility also offers the General Service Time-of-Day 2 rate to customers with a 12-month demand less than 10 kW. Prices under this schedule are higher during the High Cost Hours of 2-6 P.M. from May to September.

MidAmerican Energy offers its commercial and industrial customers a set of optional time-of-use rates with very large (up to four to five times) differences in energy or demand charges between off-peak (10 P.M. to 8 A.M. every day) and peak (1-6 P.M. weekdays) periods in the summer. Other hours (8 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 6-10 P.M. on weekdays, as well as non-off-peak hours on weekends and holidays) are also heavily discounted relative to peak prices.

Duke Energy offers time-of-use rates to its medium voltage (34,500 volts or lower; Rate DT) commercial customers with an average monthly demand of at least 500 kW, as well as to customers who take their electricity at transmission voltage (greater than 69,000 volts; Rate TT). Customers can save money by shifting electricity usage away from on-peak hours when demand charges are much higher than those during off-peak hours. On-peak hours occur on weekdays from 11 A.M. - 8 P.M. during summer as well as 9 A.M. - 2 P.M. and 5-9 P.M. in the winter, excluding holidays.

Central Maine Power (CMP) offers several time-of-use rates for various customer classes. Customers can save money be shifting consumption away from on-peak periods (7 AM - 12 PM and 4 - 8 PM, weekdays excluding holidays).

Versant Power (formerly known as Emera Maine) offers time-of-use rates for large commercial customers. Customers under this rate can save money by shifting consumption away from on-peak periods  (7 AM - 12 PM and 4 - 8 PM, weekdays excluding holidays).

A&N Electric Cooperative (ANEC) offers a time-of-use service rate (TOU-B) for customers to enroll in and save money by reducing their peak energy demand. On-peak hours occur on non-holidays weekdays from 3-8 P.M. during the summer months (June-September) and 6-8 A.M. and 3-8 P.M. during the winter months.

Baltimore Gas and Electric Company's (BGE's) Schedule GL is the default rate for customers between 60 and 600 kW and is a fixed time-of-use rate in which there are peak, intermediate (shoulder), and off-peak periods, with significant price differences between periods, especially in the summer (June through September). The summer peak runs from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. on (non-holiday) weekdays, while there are two daily peaks on non-summer weekdays, 7 to 11 A.M. and 5 to 9 P.M.

TOU.hidden_program_name: Primary Time of Use Service Rate
TOU.description: Choptank Electric Cooperative offers a Primary Time of Use service rate (Rate Schedule PT) for customers to enroll in and save money by reducing their peak energy demand. On-peak hours are defined as weekdays from 2-6 P.M. during the summer season (June-September). There are no on-peak periods during the non-summer months.

PEPCO offers a series of default time-of-use ("time-metered") rates for its commercial customers who do not choose 3rd-party electricity supply, with charges differing according to time-of-day and season. Customers can save money by shifting energy usage away from on-peak periods (12-8 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays) during the summer months of June through October.

Eversource offers time-of-use rates to medium and large commercial/industrial customers with peak and non-peak pricing and periods that differ by season and by location. Check the utility website for details on the peak periods and price differential for the relevant section of the utility's territories. The utility also has offered an optional time-of-use rate to commercial and industrial customers with a demand of less than 100 kW who can reduce their load during times of peak demand. These peak periods are from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. on weekdays during June through September, and 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. on weekdays during October through May. This optional TOU rate is closed to new customers until further notice.

National Grid offers a variety of time-of-use rates to customers whose average energy demand will exceed 200 kW. Customers on this rate are able to save money by shifting energy use away from the peak hours of 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays. Customers can also access price schedules for E.V. charging stations  through this rate. These schedules are based on customers' energy demand and usage.

Unitil offers a time-of-use rate to its medium-sized commercial customers with either average monthly energy usage between 850-120,000 kWh per month, or energy demand above 4 kW. This rate provides lower pricing during off peak hours, which run from 10 P.M. to 10 A.M. during non-holiday weekdays and all day on holidays and weekends. This rate is not accepting new customers who are not already enrolled in the rate as of 2011.

DTE's commercial and industrial customers can take advantage of a "dynamic peak pricing" option (a time-of-use rate where peak prices are several times higher on announced critical peak days but lower at all other times). Critical peak pricing will be limited to no more than 56 hours per year. Customers will be notified no less than 6 hours before critical peak hours are expected to occur. On non-critical peak days, prices are highest during on-peak hours (3 to 7 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays), lower during mid-peak hours (7 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 7 to 11 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays), and lowest during off peak hours (all other hours).

Wisconsin Public Service Corporation (WPS) provides a time-of-use option with attractive terms for commercial customers in Michigan who can switch a significant portion of their usage to off-peak periods. Customers can choose between two peak hour options. Prices are higher during on-peak periods, which for option 1 occur on non-holiday weekdays from 10 A.M.  to 6 P.M. during the summer (May through September) as well as 9 to 11 A.M. and 5 to 8 P.M. during the winter (October to April). For option 2, on-peak hours begin and end one hour later for the summer and evening on-peak winter periods.

Otter Tail Power Company offers non-residential customers Time-of-Use rate options which allow customers to save money by shifting their energy usage away from on-peak periods. Customers with a measured demand of at least 20 kW within the last 12 months can take advantage of the General Service Time of Use rate and choose from three time-of-use price periods depending on the season. Customers with a peak demand over 80 kW can take advantage of the Large General Service Time-of-Day Rate, which provides utility bill savings for shifting electricity usage away from the on peak periods of 7 A.M. to 11 A.M. during the winter (October to May) and 1-7 P.M. in the summer (June to September) on non-holiday weekdays. Energy charges are lower during shoulder periods and lowest during off-peak periods.

Mississippi Power offers the Large General Service Time-Of-Use Rate  (GS-TOU-17) and Large Power Time-Of-Use Electric Service Rate  (LPO-TOU-16). Both rates charge increased prices for energy usage during peak periods, allowing customers to save money by shifting energy usage away from these peak periods. Peak periods are 12 to 8 P.M. Monday through Friday from April through October, and 6 to 10 A.M. and 6 P.M. to 10 P.M. Monday through Friday from November through March. Prices are lower during shoulder hours, which run from 10 A.M. to 12 P.M. and 8 P.M. to 10 P.M. Monday through Friday during the summer (June to September), and lowest during off-peak hours.

Montana-Dakota Utilities offers time-of-use rates for small and large commercial and industrial customers. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use away from peak hours (12 to 8 P.M. Monday through Friday), particularly during June through September.

The Omaha Public Power District's General Service Time-of-Use Rider provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer. On-peak hours are defined as 12 to 10 P.M., weekdays from June 1 to September 15.

NV Energy offers several optional time-of-use rates, which provide utility cost savings for customers who can shift a portion of their electricity use, or peak power draws, away from on-peak hours. These on-peak hours apply to the summer months from June 1 to September 30 in Northern and Southern Nevada (from 3 - 9 P.M.). Under these rate schedules customers pay substantially less for energy use (or peak power draws) during off-peak hours and more during on-peak hours, especially during summer months.

Liberty Utilities (Granite State Electric) offers its commercial customers their General Service Time-of-Use Rate, with off-peak energy (kWh) charges lower than the on-peak rate. Off-peak hours are from 9 P.M. to 8 A.M. Monday through Friday, and all day on Saturday, Sundays and holidays. Peak hours are 8 A.M. - 9 P.M. Monday through Friday, excluding holidays.

Unitil offers a General Service and Large General Service EV Time-of-Use Rate to its commercial customers. The rate is seasonal with a winter (November through April) and summer (May through October) season. Off-peak hours are from 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. and all holidays and weekends; mid-peak hours are from 6 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday through Friday (except holidays) and on-peak hours (when rates are highest) take place from 3 to 8 P.M. Monday through Friday (except holidays).

Orange and Rockland's (O&R) commercial customers are eligible to enroll in the utility's time-of-use rates and save on their bills by reducing their usage during peak demand times. Peak demand  time in the summer months (June-September) are between 12 and 7 P.M. Monday to Friday (except holidays). Peak demand times in the winter months (October to May) are between 10 A.M. and 9 P.M., Monday to Friday (except holidays).

PSE&G's default rates  for commercial and industrial customers are either time-of-use – for those on the General Lighting & Power (GLP) or Large Power & Lighting - Secondary (LPL-S) rates – or "hourly" (i.e., real-time) for customers on their Large Power & Lighting - Primary (LPL-P) or high tension (HTS-S and HTS-HV) rates.

TOU.utility _name: Public Service Company of New Mexico
TOU.description: PNM offers numerous time-of-use rates for commercial customers in New Mexico. These rates help customers to save money on their utility bills by allowing them to shift electricity usage to off-peak hours, especially during June, July, and August. On-peak hours are defined as 8 A.M. to 8 P.M., Monday through Friday.

TOU.utility _name: Public Service Company of New Mexico
TOU.description: PNM offers that non-residential charging station pilot rate, a time-of-use rate that allows customers to save on energy costs by shifting the charging of electric vehicles away from on-peak hours (Summer 5:00 PM - 10:00 PM Monday - Sunday Non-Summer: 5:00 AM - 8:00 AM and 5:00 PM - 8:00 PM Monday - Sunday).

Xcel offers time-of-use rates for commercial and irrigation customers in New Mexico. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours during the summer. On-peak hours are defined as 12 – 6 P.M., Monday – Friday, from June through September.

Small commercial customers can opt for ConEd's time-of-use rate, which charges dramatically more or less, respectively, for power during the day (8 A.M. to 10 P.M.) versus overnight. Peak rates during non-summer months (October through May) are 24.12¢/kWh versus 1.79¢/kWh during off-peak hours. The difference is doubled during summer months (June through September), when electricity during the day is charged at 48.98¢/kWh, while at night it goes for just 1.79¢/kWh.

National Grid offers the Large General time-of-use rate (SC-3A), a day-ahead hourly rate, to its large commercial customers. By gauging day-ahead pricing, customers can plan their load reduction strategies around high-price periods and, in turn, benefit from shifting load to lower-priced periods.

Orange and Rockland's (O&R) commercial customers are eligible to enroll in the utility's time-of-use rates and save on their bills by reducing their usage during peak demand times. Peak demand  time in the summer months (June-September) are between 12 and 7 P.M. Monday to Friday (except holidays). Peak demand times in the winter months (October to May) are between 10 A.M. and 9 P.M., Monday to Friday (except holidays).
PSE&G customers can also enroll in optional time-of-use rates and save energy costs by shifting demand away from peak demand times (3 PM - 7 PM Weekdays).
RG&E customers can also enroll in time-of-use rates and save energy costs by shifting demand away from peak demand times (7 A.M. - 9 P.M.).

Duke Energy Carolinas offers Optional Power Service Time-of-Use  rates for non-residential customers. This rate provides utility bill savings (particularly, reduced demand charges) for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months. On-peak hours occur on weekdays in the summer from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., and in the winter from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M. Customers can save money through shifting energy use to off-peak hours as well as discount hours, which run from 1 A.M. to 6 A.M. on all summer days and the periods of 1-3 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on all winter days. Only the Optional Power Service Time-of-Use with Voltage Differential rate is currently accepting new customers; the Optional Power Service Time-of-Use, Energy-only rate is closed.

Duke Energy Progress offers a variety of time-of-use rates to customers who can reduce energy costs by shifting load away from on-peak periods. These include time of use rates for small, medium and large general service, and churches. On-peak hours occur on weekdays in the summer from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., and in the winter from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M. Customers can save money through shifting energy use to off-peak hours as well as discount hours, which run from 1 A.M. to 6 A.M. on all summer days and the periods of 1-3 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on all winter days. On peak hours are defined differently for the church time-of-use service. For the Duke Energy Carolinas service area, time of use rates are only available for small general service.

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company offers multiple Electric Vehicle Time-of-Use rates. These rates allows customers to save on energy costs by shifting the charging of electric vehicles away from on-peak hours (2-7 P.M. weekdays excluding company-observed holidays).
Idaho Power's Primary Time of Use Rate (Schedule 9) provides utility bill savings for commercial/industrial customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer.

Pacific Power offers two time-of-use rates. One (Schedule 210) is available for small commercial customers and provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity away from on-peak hours, 4-8 P.M. (April-October) or 6-10 A.M. and 5-8 P.M. (November - March). The other (Schedule 29) is for customers with low load-factors that don't use a lot of energy (kWh) relative to their peak demand (kW). On-peak hours are 4-8 P.M. (April-October) or 6-10 A.M. and 5-8 P.M. (November-March).
Portland General Electric's Time of Use Rate  provides utility bill savings for non-residential customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours  (every day from 10 PM - 6 AM).
PECO offers Time-Of-Use Pricing rate. Customers can save money by reducing their energy consumption during peak periods (2 - 6 PM, Weekdays).

Dominion Energy offers numerous time-of-use rates to commercial and industrial customers. Customers can save money by shifting load from away from on-peak periods. On-peak hours occur 2 - 7 P.M. Monday-Friday from June-September and 7 AM - 12 PM Monday-Friday from October to May.

Duke Energy Carolinas offers the Optional Power Service Time-of-Use rate for non-residential customers. This rate provides utility bill savings (particularly, reduced demand charges) for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months. On-peak hours are defined as 1-9 P.M, Monday – Friday, from June 1 to September 30, and 6 A.M. – 1 P.M, Monday – Friday, October 1 to May 31.

Duke Energy Progress offers a variety of time-of-use (TOU) rates to customers in South Carolina who can reduce energy costs by shifting load away from on-peak periods. These include the large general service TOU rate and large general service curtailable TOU rate. On-peak hours occur on weekdays in the summer from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., and in the winter from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M. Customers can save money through shifting energy use to off-peak hours as well as discount hours, which run from 1 A.M. to 6 A.M. on all summer days and the periods of 1-3 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on all winter days. On peak hours are defined differently for the curtailable rate service.

Xcel Energy offers numerous time of use rates for commercial customers in Texas. This rate provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer. On-peak hours are defined as 1 – 7 P.M., Monday – Friday, from June through September.

Burlington Electric Department (BED) offers time-of-use rate options to its Small General Service and Large General Service customers. Energy and demand charges are higher during on-peak summer (June 1—September 30, 12-6 P.M.) and winter (December 1—March 31, 6 A.M. to 10 P.M.).

Green Mountain Power's Commercial and Industrial Time-of-Use Rate is available to all small commercial, industrial, and agricultural customers on an optional basis and is required for customers that consume more than 7,600 kWh per month or with peak loads greater than 200 kW. Peak hours run from 6 A.M. to 11 P.M. on weekdays. This rate can help customers with demand flexibility reduce energy costs through lower off-peak kW and kWh rates.

Green Mountain Power (GMP) offers a Critical Peak Rider, in which customers, with notice by 3PM the prior day, are charged over $0.40/kWh during critical peak hours instead of the normal on-peak charges during the period of 6 A.M.—11 P.M on weekdays. Charges during the regular on and off peak hours are also significantly discounted compared to GMP's standard time-of-use rates. GMP may call a critical peak period on any day, within one hour's notice, for unforeseen events such as power plant outages, wholesale energy price spikes, or other system emergency conditions. No more than eight hours per day or 150 hours per calendar year can be deemed critical peak.

Green Mountain Power offers the Energy Storage System Service, which is available to General Service Non-Time-of-Use customers, allows them to lease or purchase eligible energy storage equipment owned by GMP. Customers in this program give GMP control of the equipment for use of the stored energy during periods of peak demand. There is no limit on the number of events, which occur on average six to eight times per month. Customers are remunerated for the energy they share with GMP during these periods while also having a backup power supply during times of power outages. Customers can pay $55 per month for a 120-month term ($6,600 total lease payment) or a single up-front payment of $5,500.

The Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) Program is available to Green Mountain Power (GMP)'s small commercial customers, allowing them to purchase and install an energy storage system. Customers can enroll the equipment into GMP's energy management platform and give access to GMP to utilize the stored energy during periods of peak demand, in exchange for generous incentive payments of roughly $900/kW for equipment that can relieve customer load on the utility for three or four hours. Peak events occur around 5 to 8 times per month and customers will be notified at least 4 hours in advance. Participants cannot be on any time-of-use rates.

A&N Electric Cooperative offers a time-of-use rate for commercial customers to enroll in and save money by reducing their peak energy demand. Energy prices are higher during the on-peak hours of 3-8 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays during the summer (June through September). There are additional on-peak hours from 6-8 A.M. during the winter months.

A&N Electric Cooperative offers a Curtailable Service Rider for customers who can reduce their load by at least 25 kW during curtailment periods. In exchange, customers will receive a monthly interruptible demand credit. Customers will receive notification of curtailment periods 5-15 minutes, or a mutually agreed upon time, depending on the time of day and the method of notification.

TOU.program_name: Large General Service Time of Use Rates
TOU.hidden_program_name: Large General Service Time of Use Rates
TOU.description: Dominion Energy offers three Large General Service rates (Schedules GS-3, GS-4, and 10) that provide incentives for load reduction during times of peak electricity demand on the grid. Customers must have a peak demand over 500 kW to participate. For schedules GS-3 and GS-4, charges are highest during the on peak hours of 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. on weekdays during the summer (June to September) as well as 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. during the winter. For schedule GS-10, peak periods vary between three different options in the summer (May to September) and occur during the periods of 6 A.M. to 12 P.M. and 5-9 P.M. in the winter.

TOU.program_name: General Service Time-of-Use With Peak Time Rebate
TOU.hidden_program_name: General Service Time-of-Use With Peak Time Rebate
TOU.description: Puget Sound Energy offers the General Service Time-of-Use with Peak Time Rebate schedule to non-residential customers with a maximum demand of 50 kW. Customers can save money by shifting energy use away from times of peak demand, which occur 5-8 P.M. year-round on non-holiday weekdays as well as 7-10 A.M. during the winter (October through March). Additionally, customers can receive a peak time rebate of roughly $0.45 per kWh in exchange for reducing energy use during certain events called by PSE. Notification of events will be issued the day before. PSE will call a maximum of 20 event days per year. Participation in this schedule is limited to 4,000 customers.

Puget Sound Energy hosts the Up & Go Electric for Fleet, a time-of-use rate for electric vehicle charging stations. Customers can earn between $10 and $165 per charger as a monthly credit if they can shift their charging to off peak hours, 10 P.M. to 6 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. All customers with PSE-supported EV supply equipment are automatically enrolled in this program.

Seattle City Light's large customer default general service rates are time-of-use ones, with peak and off-peak periods that allow customers with load-shifting capability to save money. Peak periods are defined as 6 A.M. to 10 P.M. Monday through Saturday, excluding holidays.

PEPCO's Time-Metered General Service rates (Schedules GT-LV, GT-3A, GT-3B, and MGT-LV) provide commercial/industrial customers with time-of-use options, where off-peak usage, particularly in the summer (June through October), is significantly less expensive than during peak hours.

Alliant's commercial and industrial customers can also take advantage of  Time of Day Pricing if they can divert load away from peak hours (weekdays 11AM to 7PM, June through August, and 5 to 9 P.M., December through February) and toward off-peak times (11 P.M. to 6 A.M. on weekdays, as well as all hours on weekends and holidays). This time-of-use pricing is optional for small commercial (< 75 kW peak) customers, but mandatory for larger accounts.

Madison Gas & Electric (MGE) customers with peak loads over 20 kW are defaulted onto the company's time-of-use rates, for which weekday consumption during peak periods incurs higher prices, especially in the summer, and 9 P.M. to 10 A.M. usage (as well as all consumption during weekends and holidays) is cheapest. There are three peak periods (10 A.M. to 1 P.M., 1 to 6 P.M., and 6 to 9 P.M.), of which the second has the highest rate increase compared to off-peak periods.

We Energies (WE) offers time-of-use rates that allow customers to save on energy costs by shifting load to off-peak hours (9  PM - 9 AM, Monday - Fridays, holidays, and weekends). Customers on the time-of-use rate pay about half for energy charges for off-peak hours.

Wisconsin Public Service Corp. offers a "criticall peak pricing" (CPP) option called CG-20 Response Rewards. Customers must already be enrolled on the company's time-of-use rate (CG-20) and receive notifications (at least one hour in advance) of CPP events and then can reduce their loads during the following 2-8 hour "critical peak" period, when prices are six times higher than the standard TOU rate peak prices (and ten times the off-peak rate). In exchange, participants receive 30% lower on-peak and 10% lower off-peak prices at all other times of the year. CPP events will not exceed 300 hours per year.

Wisconsin Public Service Corps offers Time-of-use rates to their commercial and industrial customers that allow them to save on energy costs by shifting load to off-peak periods, Monday to Friday. Rates during on-peak periods are roughly triple those of off-peak periods. Customers can choose from three on- and off-peak schedules that vary based on the time of year, with the summer period from May through September and winter from October through April.

Rocky Mountain Power offers three time of use rates (see schedules 29, 46 and 48T) for commercial customers in Wyoming. These rates provide utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak periods. On-peak hours are defined as Monday - Friday 7 to 9 A.M. and 4 to 11 P.M. every day.

Real-Time Energy.description: Alabama power offers two real time pricing programs (Rates RTP and ILD) both aimed at larger customers. When subscribed to these rates, customers are alternatively credited or charged for electricity usage below or above a pre-determined customer threshold load at the utility's market rates. Participants may choose to pay for these differences based on either day-ahead or hour-ahead market pricing. Furthermore, customers may also select from a variety of price protection products, including caps, collars, contracts for differences, index swaps, and index caps. These variants on basic real-time pricing service are risk management tools that customers can use as hedges against possible periods of high, real-time electricity prices.

The California Independent System Operator (CAISO) offers its Proxy Demand Response and Reliability Demand Response programs for commercial customers capable of curtailing at least 100 kW for day-ahead and real-time energy markets or at least 500 kW for spinning and non-spinning reserves in those same markets. Participants who don't meet those minimums can bid in through an aggregator or curtailment or customer service provider (CSP) in the ISO's Proxy Demand Response program. Larger participating customers can bid directly into the wholesale day ahead or real time markets (Reliability Demand Response program). Participants must be able to fully curtail their committed load within 40 minutes of an event being called and maintain that reduction for one to four hours. CAISO can call up to 15 events or 48 total hours of curtailment per six-month term. The summer term runs from June through September and winter term from October through May.

Through the Emergency Load Reduction Program (ELRP), SCE participants receive an incentive to reduce their energy during times of high grid stress and emergencies. Customers must be able to reduce load by just 1 kW during an event. To enroll, customers must not be must not be currently participating in a DR program with the exception of the Base Interruptible Program, Summer Discount Plan or Agricultural and Pumping Interruptible Program. Additionally customers may be enrolled in either the Real-Time Pricing or Critical Peak Pricing rate plans. Events occur between May and October, and can be called any day of the week between 4-9 P.M., lasting anywhere from one to five hours. Events may be called on consecutive days, depending on grid conditions. Customers will not be asked to participate for more than 60 hours per year. Participation in this program is entirely voluntary and there are no financial penalties if the customer does not meet its load reduction nomination. Participants will earn $2/kWh for load reduction during an event.

Southern California Edison's (SCE) commercial and industrial customers can enroll in SCE's Real-Time Pricing (RTP) Program. Customers participating in the program  are incentivized to reduce load or shift their demand to lower-priced hours. Pricing under this program is based on the time of day, season, and prior-day temperature, providing customers with multiple pricing options to choose from. The summer season is defined as June through September and winter season as October through May. Customers can receive day-ahead notifications of hourly prices via SCE's DR alerts app. Customers enrolled in the RTP program can also enroll in other SCE demand response programs.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets. Customers with active demand resources (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output) can participate in the Real-Time and Day-Ahead Energy Markets. These markets provide customers an opportunity to receive payments for responding to system prices or providing operating reserves that help maintain electric system reliability.

Georgia Power offers a number of real-time pricing rates. Customers on these rate schedules are alternatively credited or charged for electricity usage below or above a pre-determined customer baseline load (CBL). Participants may choose to pay for these differences from their CBL based on either day-ahead or hour-ahead market pricing. Furthermore, customers may also select from a variety of price protection products, including caps, collars, contracts for differences, index swaps, and index caps. These variants on the basic real-time pricing service are risk management tools that customers can use as a hedge during periods of higher real-time electricity prices.

Idaho Power's FlexPeak Management program is a highly customizable demand response program that utilizes web-based software to provide real-time energy information to manage energy use and reduce peak load during the program period (June 15 – August 15, 3-10 P.M., Monday through Friday). Commercial and industrial customers who are able to reduce a minimum of 20kW when an event is called are eligible. Participants receive financial incentives for agreeing to be "on call" to respond within four hours to demand reduction events. A fixed payment up to $3.25/kW per week is paid even for weeks when events are not called. For weeks when an event is called, customers will receive the incentive payments based on the actual kW reduction achieved during the event. After four events are called in a season, additional incentives of $0.20/kWh are provided for actual energy reductions during events, which last from two to four hours each.
Small commercial customers are eligible to enroll in the Ameren's Real Time Pricing (Rider RTP) offering, an hourly priced option based on the relevant MISO delivery point.

ComEd commercial customers who do not opt for third-party supply are defaulted on to the company's Basic Electric Service Hourly Pricing (BESH), a real-time rate that floats with the wholesale electricity market in the area.

Duke Energy offers a set of real-time pricing options through its PathWise™ initiative. This program allows customers to take advantage of lower prices when electricity is cheaper to produce. For more information on PathWise™ , email BSCteam@duke-energy.com.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets. Customers with active demand resources (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output) can participate in the Real-Time and Day-Ahead Energy Markets. These markets provide customers an opportunity to receive payments for responding to system prices or providing operating reserves that help maintain electric system reliability.

Delmarva Power's Hourly-Priced Service Rider is a real-time pricing option whereby customers pay Delmarva PJM's locational marginal price plus fixed adders for distribution, administration, etc. This rate is mandatory for customers over 600 kW who do not contract with a 3rd-party electricity supplier.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets. Customers with active demand resources (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output) can participate in the Real-Time and Day-Ahead Energy Markets. These markets provide customers an opportunity to receive payments for responding to system prices or providing operating reserves that help maintain electric system reliability.

Upper Peninsula Power Company offers a real-time pricing option for customers with over 1,000 kW of demand. Hourly energy charges are based on the applicable Local Marginal Price (LMP) and applicable Midwest Independent System Operator (MISO) charges and credits. Through this rate customers have access to both Real-Time LMP pricing and a Day Ahead Bidding Option.

Otter Tail Power Company's Real Time Pricing Rider is available to a limited number of customers with at least 200 kW of permanent load. Customers pay at the company's real-time rate for usage above and below a historically determined customer baseline load. The rider is currently closed to new customers until further notice.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets. Customers with active demand resources (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output) can participate in the Real-Time and Day-Ahead Energy Markets. These markets provide customers an opportunity to receive payments for responding to system prices or providing operating reserves that help maintain electric system reliability.

Real-Time Energy.hidden_program_name: Basic Generation Service-Commercial Industrial Energy Price
Real-Time Energy.description: Orange and Rockland's (O&R) commercial customers can choose to have their electric supply priced on an hourly basis by enrolling in the Basic Generation Service-Commercial Industrial Energy Price (BGS-CIEP) plan, a real-time pricing rate. Energy charges will vary each hour of the day, and every day of the week based on market conditions.

NYISO's Day Ahead Demand Response Program (DADRP) provides electricity users with the opportunity to bid load reductions into New York's day-ahead wholesale electricity market, where their bids compete with generators' offers to meet the state's demand. At their discretion, customers can submit bids on a day-ahead basis by indicating the load reduction amount, price (between NYISO's "monthly net benefits test offer floor" and $2,000 per MWh), and time period. If a bid is accepted and the customer fully curtails, they receive payment based on the greater of their bid price and the day-ahead locational-based marginal price (LBMP). If the customer fails to fully curtail, they will pay the higher of the day-ahead LBMP and the real-time price for the amount of incomplete scheduled load reduction. Individual customers can either participate directly in DADRP, if their load reduction is at least 1 MW, or through an authorized curtailment service provider (CSP), such as a utility, energy service company, or curtailment aggregator. The minimum offered load reduction by an aggregation of electricity consumers within a load zone must be at least 2 MW. DADRP participants can also be registered in either the EDRP or SCR program.  This program is scheduled to end April 16, 2025. Customers interested in continuing their participation in NYISO's Demand Response programs can enroll in NYISO's Distributed Energy Resources Participation Model.

NYISO offers the Demand-Side Ancillary Services Program (DSASP), through which loads can provide ancillary services -- specifically, 10- and 30-minute spinning and non-spinning operating reserves – as well as frequency regulation service. To participate, registered demand-side resources submit availability bids to the day-ahead and/or real-time market. If these bids are accepted, the demand-side customer is paid the market clearing price for that level of ancillary services. In return, the customer must comply with load reduction signals from NYISO. Any differences between the day-ahead and ancillary services amount is financially settled at the real-time ancillary services prices. A demand-side resource cannot participate simultaneously in the DADRP and DSASP. This program is scheduled to end April 16, 2025. Customers interested in continuing their participation in NYISO's Demand Response programs can enroll in NYISO's Distributed Energy Resources Participation Model.

The New York Independent Systeom Operator (NYISO) offers several programs that compensate demand flexible resources. The newest is the Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) Participation Model. It allows distributed energy resources (including demand response through demand reductions and/or behind-the-meter generators) of at least 10 kW to participate in the NYISO-administered markets. DERs that are dispatchable in real-time are able to provide energy, ancillary services, and capacity. DERs such as demand res;ponse must register first as an aggregation; a sizable demand response resource may register as an aggregation by itself or be combined with other, similar resources for dispatch. More details on aggregation and registration to participate in NYISO's markets may be found in https://www.nyiso.com/documents/20142/2923301/M-38-Aggregation-Final-v1-0.pdf/488117aa-43ec-85c3-423d-4aba592e5895?t=1713279580926.

NYISO offers the Emergency Demand Response Program (EDRP) which provides financial incentives for electricity users to voluntarily reduce consumption or operate on-site generation to reduce their electricity draw from the grid during periods of electricity reserve shortage or reliability need. NYISO typically provides two-hour notice of curtailment events as well as day-ahead advisories (although in some cases immediate deployment is requested). Participants receive the higher of $500/MWh and the real-time zonal locational-based marginal price (LBMP) for their curtailments. Participation in any curtailment event is voluntary, and there are no penalties for non-performance. An individual customer can either participate directly in EDRP (if it can offer at least 100 kW of load cut) as its own curtailment service provider (CSP) or through an authorized third-party CSP, such as a utility, energy service company, or curtailment aggregator. Customers cannot participate in both the EDRP and the Installed Capacity Special Case Resources (SCR) program, as SCR and EDRP are sometimes dispatched simultaneously by NYISO.

Real-Time Energy.hidden_program_name: Basic Generation Service-Commercial Industrial Energy Price
Real-Time Energy.description: Orange and Rockland's (O&R) commercial customers can choose to have their electric supply priced on an hourly basis by enrolling in the Basic Generation Service-Commercial Industrial Energy Price (BGS-CIEP) plan, a real-time pricing rate. Energy charges will vary each hour of the day, and every day of the week based on market conditions.

Real-time pricing is available to Duke Energy Carolinas' large customers (demand of 1,000 kW or greater) through the Hourly Pricing rate schedule. Customers are notified of the hourly energy prices for the following day and are alternatively credited or charged, based on the hourly price, for usage below or above a pre-determined customer baseline load profile.

Real-time pricing is available to Duke Energy Progress' large customers (demand of 1,000 kW or greater) through the Hourly Pricing rate schedule. Customers are notified of the hourly energy prices for the following day and are alternatively credited or charged, based on the hourly price, for usage below or above a pre-determined customer baseline load profile.

Otter Tail Power Company's Real Time Pricing Rider is available to a limited number of customers with at least 200 kW of permanent load. Customers pay at the company's real-time rate for usage above and below a historically determined customer baseline load.
Duke Energy offers a set of real-time pricing options through its PathWise™ initiative. For more information on the Pathwise™ program, contact BSCteam@duke-energy.com.

Duke Energy's Real Time Pricing program (Rate RTP) allows customers to lower their electricity costs by either shifting load from higher to lower cost pricing periods and adding new load during lower cost pricing periods or by learning about market pricing. Binding price quotes will be sent to each customer on a day-ahead basis.

Ohio Edison, a First Energy subsidiary utility, offers numerous real-time and combination fixed and variable (e.g., "block-and-swing) electric rates. Customers can save money by shifting use to off-peak periods.

The Illuminating Company, a First Energy subsidiary utility, offers numerous real-time and combination fixed and variable (e.g., "block-and-swing) electric rates. Customers can save money by shifting use to off-peak periods.

Toledo Edison, a First Energy subsidiary utility, offers numerous real-time and combination fixed and variable (e.g., "block-and-swing) electric rates. Customers can save money by shifting use to off-peak periods.

Idaho Power offers the Flex Peak Management program, a highly customizable demand response program that utilizes web-based software to provide real-time energy information to manage energy use and reduce peak load during the program period (June 15 – September 15, 3-10 P.M., weekdays). Commercial and industrial customers who are able to reduce a minimum of 20 kW are eligible for this program. Participants receive financial incentives for agreeing to be "on call" to respond within four hours to demand reduction events. Additional incentives are provided for actual demand reductions during events, which last from two to four hours each. Incentive payments are based on the amount of energy pledged and reduced, as well as the frequency of demand response events.

First Energy customers in the Met-Ed, Penn Power, Penelec, and West Penn Power service areas can also enroll in an Hourly-Pricing Default Service rider. Energy charges are provided at the day-ahead PJM locational marginal prices based on the customer's real-time metered hourly load.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets. Customers with active demand resources (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output) can participate in the Real-Time and Day-Ahead Energy Markets. These markets provide customers an opportunity to receive payments for responding to system prices or providing operating reserves that help maintain electric system reliability.

Real-time pricing is available to Duke Energy Carolinas' large customers (demand of 1,000 kW or greater) through the Hourly Pricing rate schedule. Customers are notified of the hourly energy prices for the following day and are alternatively credited or charged, based on the hourly price, for usage below or above a pre-determined customer baseline load profile.

Real-time pricing is available to Duke Energy Progress' large customers (demand of 1,000 kW or greater) through the Hourly Pricing rate schedule. Customers are notified of the hourly energy prices for the following day and are alternatively credited or charged, based on the hourly price, for usage below or above a pre-determined customer baseline load profile.

Otter Tail Power Company's Real Time Pricing Rider is available to a limited number of customers with at least 200 kW of permanent load. Customers pay at the company's real-time rate for usage above and below a historically determined customer baseline load.

Load Resource Participation in the ERCOT Markets: Customers who are capable of managing their load and can meet certain performance requirements may qualify to become "load resources." Qualified load resources may participate in ERCOT's real-time energy market and/or provide operating reserves to the ERCOT ancillary services markets (non-spinning reserves or frequency regulation), which require very quick responses. Load resources participating in ERCOT's real-time energy market submit bids to buy power up to a specified price level and are instructed by ERCOT to reduce load if wholesale market prices equal or exceed that level. Load resources that are scheduled or selected in ERCOT's day-ahead ancillary services markets are eligible to receive a capacity payment regardless of whether they are actually curtailed. A load resource needs to register with ERCOT and must be represented by a "qualified scheduling entity" that is responsible for market operations and financial settlement.

Rocky Mountain Power's Demand Response program provides financial incentives to customers who are able to reduce electricity use during peak demand periods. There are two participation options: advanced dispatch notice and real-time dispatch. Customers participating in the advanced dispatch notice option receive alerts at least seven minutes prior to an event which lasts between 5 minutes and 4 hours. Customers participating in the real-time dispatch option receive no advanced notice and use auto curtailment to reduce load, event duration lasts from 3 to 7 minutes. Program participants can earn financial incentives up to $100/kW for participation in the advanced dispatch or real-time program. Program participants who participate in both programs can earn incentives up to $175/kW.

Burlington Electric Department (BED) offers monthly Electric Vehicle Charging Credits to customers on Small General and Large General Service Rates with BED approved devices. Customers will receive credit for charging their vehicle during the approved EV charging hours. Customers on the Small General Service Rate will receive energy credits of $0.080 per kWh and customers on the Large General Service Rate will receive demand credits of $23.61 per kW when EV charging occurs during the approved EV charging hours. Three options are offered through this program: Fixed EV Charging, Flexible Load, and Flexible Real-time. Approved EV charging hours are based on the option the customers choose and will be determined by BED.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets. Customers with active demand resources (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output) can participate in the Real-Time and Day-Ahead Energy Markets. These markets provide customers an opportunity to receive payments for responding to system prices or providing operating reserves that help maintain electric system reliability.

WE Energies offers real-time pricing rates that allow customers to save on energy costs by shifting load to off-peak periods, typically during period of compromised grid reliability or price spikes in the wholesale electricity market.

Wisconsin Public Service Corps customers can enroll in a real-time market pricing rate that charges them varying hourly prices, which are quoted one day or less in advance. Customers can save money by reducing their energy usage during periods of peak demand.

Interruptible/Curtailable.description: Alabama Power offers a Interruptible Capacity Credit Rider (IC) option to customers who are able to curtail their load during times of high demand. There are three options that offer different remuneration rates and terms. Option 1 offers customers $2.55 per kW per month. Curtailment events last a maximum of eight hours and occur no more than fives days per week. A maximum of 200 hours of curtailment events may be called under Option 1. Customers enrolled in Option 2 receive a lower remuneration payment, $2.02 per kW  per month enrolled, but are only subjected to 100 curtailment hours per year, and curtailment events are limited to three days per week. Curtailment events under Options 2 and 3 also last no more than eight hours. Option 3 offers a lower remuneration payment, $0.98 per kW per month enrolled but are only subjected to 50 hours per year, and curtailment events are limited to one day per week.

Chugach Electric Association has an interruptible rate (Schedule 27) available to secondary voltage customers with peak demands over 100 kW in the North District. In exchange for their willingness to be interrupted, customers on this tariff are not assessed a demand charge. The utility also has site-specific interruptible service rates for some U.S. military sites, allowing the utility or sites to start onsite generation and curtail all utility-served load.

Tucson Electric Power (TEP) offers the Interruptible Service Program to commercial customers for agreeing to electric service interruptions during times of high demand. These events can occur from May through September and any given day can have at most two six-hour events. TEP provides 30-minute notices prior to an interruption. Bill credits are issued monthly based on the kilowatt (kW) capacity that customers agree to curtail and TEP's "market value capacity price" (MVCP). The program is only available to customers with demand that exceeds 3,000 kW, and participating customers must agree to curtail at least 1,000 kW at a single service point. Interested customers may subscribe between March 15th-April 15th of each program year. The program is closed to new subscriptions for the 2024 program year but will reopen in March for customers interested in participating in the 2025 program year.

The Optional Interruptible Service Rider (OISR) from Entergy Arkansas is for customers who can interrupt at least 100 kW of load throughout the year during on-peak hours. On-peak hours are defined as 1-8 P.M. on weekdays during the summer months (June – September), and 7 A.M.-6 P.M. in other months. Program participants can save on utility bills through a reduction in demand charges. Participants must have appropriate metering and communications equipment installed, and penalty charges apply if the agreed-upon load is not curtailed when requested. Customers will be notified of a curtailment event via email or any other mutually acceptable method by 4:30 P.M. the previous day (day-ahead notice). The day-ahead notice also provides customers an estimated event starting time. Actual starting times must occur within four hours of the estimate. Curtailment events may occur up to ten days per month and last no more than four hours per event in the summer and three hours per event in other months. In the summer months, only one curtailment event may be called per day, but the rest of the year up to two events may be called each day. If emergency conditions exist, Entergy may call upon customers to reduce their load by more than their contracted demand during on-peak hours, and provide a 30-minute notification via a mutually acceptable method.

Southwestern Electric Power Company (SWEPCO) offers the Experimental Curtailable Service Rider to customers with loads larger than 500 kW. As little as ten minutes' notice is provided for emergency curtailments and 30 minutes' notice for non-emergency curtailments. Customers receive an incentives for curtailing load upon request. This rider is available only in conjunction with the company's Lighting and Power or Large Lighting and Power rate schedules.

Through the Emergency Load Reduction Program (ELRP), PG&E participants receive an incentive to reduce their energy during times of high grid stress and emergencies. Customers must be able to reduce load by just 1 kW during an event. To enroll, customers must not be must not be currently participating in a DR program with the exception of the Base Interruptible Program. Additionally customers may be enrolled in the Peak Day Pricing rate plan. Events occur between May and October, and can be called any day of the week between 4-9 P.M., lasting anywhere from one to five hours. Events may be called on consecutive days, depending on grid conditions. Customers will not be asked to participate for more than 60 hours per year. Participation in this program is entirely voluntary and there are no financial penalties if the customer does not meet its load reduction nomination. Participants will earn $2/kWh for load reduction during an event.

Southern California Edison (SCE) offers the Agricultural and Pumping Interruptible Program (AP-I), which helps customers save on energy costs in exchange for allowing SCE to temporarily interrupt electric service during times of peak demand. Eligible customers must have a demand of 37 kW or greater, or at least 50 horsepower of connected load. Customers allow SCE to install remote-controlled switches on their agricultural and pumping equipment that can automatically shut off the equipment when called upon by SCE. In exchange customers receive a monthly bill credit, applied year round, even when no interruptions occur. Service interruptions may occur at any time of the year, seven days a week. Events are limited to one per day, no longer than six hours per event, and 180 hours per calendar year.  Customers may request courtesy notifications via email, phone, or text message.

Southern California Edison (SCE) offers the Agricultural and Pumping Interruptible Program (AP-I), which helps customers save on energy costs in exchange for allowing SCE to temporarily interrupt electric service during times of peak demand. Eligible customers must have a demand of 37 kW or greater, or at least 50 horsepower of connected load. Customers allow SCE to install remote-controlled switches on their agricultural and pumping equipment that can automatically shut off the equipment when called upon by SCE. In exchange customers receive a monthly bill credit, applied year round, even when no interruptions occur. Service interruptions may occur at any time of the year, seven days a week. Events are limited to one per day, no longer than six hours per event, and 180 hours per calendar year.  Customers may request courtesy notifications via email, phone, or text message.

Through the Emergency Load Reduction Program (ELRP), SDG&E participants receive an incentive to reduce their energy during times of high grid stress and emergencies. Customers must be able to reduce load by just 1 kW during an event. To enroll, customers must not be must not be currently participating in a DR program with the exception of the Base Interruptible Program. Events occur between May and October, and can be called any day of the week between 4-9 P.M., lasting anywhere from one to five hours. Events may be called on consecutive days, depending on grid conditions. Customers will not be asked to participate for more than 60 hours per year. Participation in this program is entirely voluntary and there are no financial penalties if the customer does not meet its load reduction nomination. Participants will earn $2/kWh for load reduction during an event.

Xcel Energy's Critical Peak Pricing Program allows commercial and industrial customers to save money on energy costs by shifting electrical vehicle charging to off-peak hours during critical peak pricing events. Critical peak pricing events can be called from 2 to 10 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays and last no more than four hours. These events can occur up to 15 times per year, but not more than once per day. Customers will receive notification via email, text, or voice message no later than 4 P.M. the previous day. Customers cannot participate in the EV Critical Peak Pricing Program and also receive the Xcel Energy's Interruptible Service Option Credit.

Xcel Energy's Interruptible Service Option Credit (ISOC) provides opportunities for significant electric bill savings to customers who agree to reduce their electricity demand during periods of peak energy demand.  To participate customers must be able to cut at least 300 kW of load for a minimum of four hours when events are called. The monthly credit a customer receives is based on the customer's contract interruptible load (the median of the customer's maximum daily 1-hour integrated kW demands occurring between noon and 8 P.M. on weekdays, excluding holidays, from June 1 through September 30th of the previous year), the customers maximum annual hours of interruption, and the advance notice needed, so it ranges widely. Most events occur during summer weekdays but can be called at any time. Participants can sign up for the year any time before May 31.

Florida Power and Light (FPL) provides a set of Curtailable Service rates, in which customers agree to shed 200 kW or greater "from time to time" and are remunerated each month of the year. There are penalties for non-compliance with curtailment requests. These rates are available for all areas served by the utility. The rate schedules are currently closed until further notice.

The Interruptible Standby and Supplemental Service Rate (ISST-1) offered by Florida Power and Light (FPL) remunerates customers for allowing their service to be interrupted at any time, with one hour's notice, up to 25 times per year. Each event will last no more than 6 hours. In return, customers are levied much lower demand charges, based on the firm demand to which they're willing to reduce to during events. This rate is available for customers in all areas served by the utility.

Georgia Power offers two interruptible rate options - the Demand Response Credit rider (DRC-1) pilot and the Demand Plus Energy Credit rider (DPEC-5). The DRC-1 option allows customers on the company's Resiliency Asset Service tariff to earn bill credits for at reducing, on request, least 1,000 kW of demand through a dispatchable Distributed Energy Resource (DER) installed by the company. The DPEC-5 schedule option allows customers to receive bill credits of $2.53 per kW during summer months for reducing their electric demand by at least 200 kW, and are also remunerated for actual energy reductions at $0.092 per kWh. Bill credits are paid for reductions during the months of June through September. Load curtailment requests occur on non-holiday weekdays from 12 to 8 P.M and can be issued with as little as 30 minutes' notice. A maximum of eight hours per day and 100 hours per year are subject to curtailment requests. There are significant penalties for non-compliance.

Rocky Mountain Power offers the Interruptible Power Service schedule to customers with loads of 1,000 kW or greater. Customers are remunerated based on the level of load curtailment they are able to commit to. Customers may commit to a guaranteed availability level of 60%, 70%, 80%, or 90% of their contract demand. A contract term of one year or longer is required.

AES Indiana offers various curtailable riders (particularly, riders 14-17 and 22) that permit customers to take advantage of credits both for capacity (contracted kW) and energy (actual kWh curtailed during events) in exchange for curtailing consumption or using their generators in times of grid emergencies or high wholesale power prices.

Interruptible/Curtailable.hidden_program_name: Interruptible and Direct Load Control Riders
Interruptible/Curtailable.description: CenterPoint Energy (formerly Vectren / Southern Indiana Gas and Electric) offers several interruptible riders for commercial customers in Indiana with an interruptible demand of at least 200 kW. The Interruptible Contract Rider and Interruptible Option Rider provide customers a capacity credit on their bill based on their monthly interruptible demand. In exchange, customers allow the utility to interrupt their service with ten minutes to one hour's notice. Interruptions may occur no more than 8 hours per day and 250 hours per year.
