The company also offers a direct load control ("Rider DLC") air conditioner cycling program that remunerates commercial customers at the following levels: $5 per month for each electric air conditioner or heat pump of five tons or less; $4 per month per kW for each electric air conditioner or heat pump greater than five tons; and $2 per month for each electric water heater. The DLC rider is applicable from June through September. CenterPoint Energy also encourages its customers to participate in demand response programs sponsored by MISO.

Indiana Michigan Power (an AEP company) offers several interruptible rate options to its commercial and industrial customers. These rates offer incentives based on the demand reduced at the utility's request.

Wabash Valley Power, a generation and transmission utility, provides incentives to its numerous northern Indiana distribution cooperatives for demand response through its Power Shift initiative. Most of these distribution cooperatives offer interruptible options to their large customers. Consult with your cooperative's representative to learn what opportunities are available.

Alliant Energy's Interruptible Service Option rider offers customers bill credits ($8.21/kw) in exchange for reducing consumption during peak periods when called. Customers are typically given two-hour notice to reduce usage to a pre-determined level, and must be able to curtail at least 200 kW during events.

Evergy offers the Interruptible Service Rider to customers on the Medium General Service, Large General Service or Industrial and Large Power schedules who agree to provide at least 500 kW of load available for the utility to interrupt with at least two hours' notice. Each month, customers receive incentive credits of $3 per kW of interruptible capacity in addition to $75 per MWh of actual energy usage reduced during the period of interruption.

A&N Electric Cooperative (ANEC) offers a curtailable service rider (CS-1) that allows customers to save money through reducing their peak energy demand by at least 25 kW. Customers receive bill credits for participation in curtailment events.

Choptank Electric Cooperative offers curtailable service riders (LC and LC-FI) that allow participants to save money through reducing their peak energy demand by at least 50 kW for commercial customers, and at least 25 kW for irrigation customers. Customers receive bill credits for participation in curtailment events.

Delmarva Power's Peak Management ("PM") Rider  is an interruptible/curtailable rate option that provides participants with a per-kW bill credit based on their ability to reach a pre-designated firm service level (an absolute kW load) or a guaranteed load drop from their expected power draw on similar summer weekdays. Remuneration amounts are based on prevailing PJM wholesale prices and depend on the maximum number of days (20 or 40) on which the customer is willing to curtail each summer (June through September) and the maximum number of hours (four or eight) for each curtailment. Penalties for non-compliance apply.

DTE Energy offers interruptible rates to all its commercial and industrial customers. Electricity is discounted in exchange for interruptibility in times of system need or when wholesale prices are high. Interruptible rate discounts vary from approximately 10% to 25% depending on the tariff. To participate, customers must agree to shed a minimum of 50 kW and interrupt within one hour of notification. Failure to interrupt results in a penalty for all usage above the customer's committed firm demand level (i.e., on top of the prescribed monthly rate) during the interruption period.

Upper Peninsula Power Company offers a standard interruptible rider, in which participants pay lower demand charges for committing to reduce their load to a firm service level (with at least one hour's notice) during events. Customers can choose to specify different firm demands each month or contract the same demand each month. The maximum hours of interruption will be less than 600 hours per calendar year.

Wisconsin Public Service Corporation (WPS) offers an interruptible rider, CP-I2, to commercial and industrial customers in Michigan. Participants contract for a 1000 kW or greater load reduction  subject to WPS's determination of emergency conditions on the grid. In exchange, the customer receives reduced rates for its monthly on-peak demand. Two on-peak period options are available: 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. and 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. on non-holiday weekdays. Customers will be charged for failing to interrupt load during an event unless notice is received less than one hour before interruption.

Wisconsin Public Service Corporation (WPS) provides a number of curtailment rates which compensate customers in exchange for their agreement to reduce load by a fixed amount during curtailment events. Customers will receive credits based on the curtailable demand, actual energy use and actual curtailed capacity during on peak periods. Curtailment events will occur no more than 300 hours in a given year. Customers will face penalties for failing to curtail unless notification is provided less than one hour before a curtailment event.

Xcel Energy customers can also take advantage of the company's interruptible gas rate, which offers discounted natural gas for customers who can reduce their gas usage within one hour's notice. There are penalties for failing to curtail. Customers can call 800-481-4700 to learn more or to sign up.

Dakota Electric Association offers direct load control options for air conditioners as part of its Energy Wise® initiative. On days when energy use is high, Dakota Electric will cycle participants' air conditioner condensers on and off in 15-minutes increments. Option one participants receive a credit of 3.2 cents per kWh for the electricity their air conditioner uses. A rebate of $20 per ton of cooling capacity, up to $1,500, is available to offset the cost of installing a sub-meter and load control receiver. Option two participants have a load control receiver installed by a Dakota Electric contractor and receive a rebate of $6.50 per ton of cooling load each June, July and August. Dakota Electric also offers a related interruptible program for electric water heaters, which allows participants to receive a reduced price on the electricity their water heater uses. Customers can contact 651-463-6243 for more information or to enroll.

The Minnkota Power Cooperative, serving various municipal and cooperative utilities in Minnesota, offers their members several interruptible demand response programs. Visit the program website to find demand response program options for your local cooperative.

Customers can save on natural gas costs when they enroll in Xcel Energy's Interruptible Gas Rate program. This program allows business customers to receive a one-hour notice from Xcel that they must go off the gas system and curtail their load completely during periods of peak gas demand, like cold winter mornings. A designated phone line connection to Xcel's telemetering device is required. Contact your Xcel Energy account manager or call 800-481-4700 for more information.

Xcel Energy offers the Peak Partner Rewards program to customers in Minnesota, which provides bill credits to customers who agree to reduce their energy usage during times of peak demand. Customers enrolled in this program provide a minimum of 25 kW of interruptible load from June to September. Participants are given a one-hour notice before load curtailment events, which last anywhere from one to four hours. Events are most likely to occur during weekdays from 12 to 8 P.M. There is a maximum of 15 events per year. There are two types of incentives customers can receive: monthly reservation incentives at $2 per kW of load they agree to reduce during the month, regardless of an event occuring, and an additional $1.35 per kWh of energy reduced during the event.

Evergy offers the Curtailable Demand Rider to customers in the Missouri West region who can demonstrate ability to curtail 200 kW or more of their on-peak demand. The company may call curtailment events from 12 P.M. to 10 P.M. on weekdays during the summer months (June to September). Participants receive a monthly bill credit of $2.64 per contracted kW for their curtailed demand, and even more credit per kW if they agree to contract for this rider for three or more years. The company will provide customers with at least four hours of advance notice ahead of curtailment events.

Customers are eligible for a number of interruptible rates from Montana-Dakota Utilities, including the Small Interruptible General Gas Service, Large Interruptible General Gas Service, and Interruptible Large Power Demand Response. Customers are given 10 minutes' notification before service is interrupted by the utility in exchange for lower monthly demand charges.

The Energy Curtailable Service Rider from the Nebraska Public Power District (NPPD) is for customers who can voluntarily reduce their load during an "energy curtailment period" (ECP) by a minimum of 50 kW. Each time NPPD declares an ECP, it sends advance notification to participating customers providing the start and finish times of the event, the $/kW price to be paid for load reduction, and the deadline for accepting the offer. This rider may be combined with other rider rate schedules. ECPs can last from one to twelve hours per day.

Nebraska Public Power District (NPPD) offers two interruptible rate options for large customers with at least 10 MW of curtailable demand , including the Interruptible Service Rider and the Interruptible Market-Based Rate Rider. During an event, participating customers reduce their energy usage in exchange for utility bill incentives.

Omaha Public Power District offers the Emergency/Volunteer Curtailable rider which requests customers to voluntarily curtail a minimum of 100 kW of demand periodically. Participating customers will receive a bill credit of either $5.12 (for Option 467V) or at least $10.25 (for Option 467E) per kW curtailed per event in which they choose to participate and do so successfully. Events can take place any time between 12 and 10 P.M from June 1 to September 15 and do not last more than eight hours. Customers agree to have their designated load available for curtailment within one hour.

The Interruptible Irrigation Service (IS-2) is a subsidized rate available to agricultural customers during irrigation season (March 1 to October 31). Irrigation customers on this service must agree to have load control equipment installed on their irrigation pumping. NV Energy will not shut down irrigation equipment except in an emergency situation, in which case the customer will be contacted by NV Energy at least 30 minutes prior to a curtailment event. IS-2 rates are set by the Public Utilities Commission of Nevada on an annual basis. In order to maintain the rate, customers must recertify every three years.

Customers in the Duke Energy Progress service area can enroll in the Demand Response Automation (DRA-9) rider and commit to a "contracted curtailable demand" of 50 kW or greater during peak demand periods in the summer (June through September) and winter (December through February). In exchange, customers receive a monthly credit of $4.25 per kW of summer contracted demand and event performance credit of $6 per kW of demand reductions for months with curtailment events. The customer can allow Duke Energy to install a load control device and remotely control the customer's electrical equipment, or just manually curtail its load upon notification of a curtailment event. Events last no more than eight hours and occur a maximum of ten times per year. Customers will receive a minimum of 30 minutes notice before an event is called by the utility. Customers are not subjected to the 50 kW minimum contracted curtailable demand in the winter.

The Large Load Curtailable Rider (LLC-6) is available to customers in the Duke Energy Progress area who can reduce their load by a contracted amount during curtailment periods. These periods last no longer than eight hours and may occur during on- or off-peak hours. The total hours of curtailment periods will be no more than 400 per calendar year. On-peak hours occur on weekdays in the summer from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., and in the winter from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M. Customers can save money through shifting energy use to off-peak hours as well as discount hours, which run from 1 A.M. to 6 A.M. on all summer days and the periods of 1-3 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on all winter days. In addition, there are monthly credits of $4.90 per kW of demonstrated curtailable demand. Customers are notified a minimum of 30 minutes before a curtailment period.

Customers are eligible for a number of interruptible rates from Montana-Dakota Utilities, including the Small Interruptible General Gas Service and Large Interruptible General Gas Service. Customers are given 10 minutes' notification before service is interrupted by the utility in exchange for lower monthly demand charges.

Xcel Energy customers can save on natural gas costs when they enroll in the Interruptible Gas Rate program. This program allows business customers to receive a one-hour notice from Xcel that they must go off the gas system and curtail their load completely during periods of peak gas demand, like cold winter mornings. A designated phone line connection to Xcel's telemetering device is required. Contact your Xcel Energy account manager or call 800-481-4700 for more information.

Dominion Energy offers the Interruptible Service rider to large commercial and industrial facilities that can commit to reduce 1,000 kW or greater during periods of peak demand. On-peak periods occur weekdays from 6 A.M. to 12 P.M. between November and April, and from 1 to 9 P.M. May to October. Customers are notified of curtailment periods at least four hours prior to an interruption, except during a system emergency when as little as ten minutes notice is given.

Customers in the Duke Energy Progress service area can enroll in the Demand Response Automation (DRA-9) rider and commit to a "contracted curtailable demand" of 50 kW or greater during peak demand periods in the summer (June through September) and winter (December through February). In exchange, customers receive a monthly credit of $4.25 per kW of summer contracted demand and event performance credit of $6 per kW of demand reductions for months with curtailment events. The customer can allow Duke Energy to install a load control device and remotely control the customer's electrical equipment, or just manually curtail its load upon notification of a curtailment event. Events last no more than eight hours and occur a maximum of ten times per year. Customers will receive a minimum of 30 minutes notice before an event is called by the utility. Customers are not subjected to the 50 kW minimum contracted curtailable demand in the winter.

The Large Load Curtailable Rider (Rider LLC) is available to customers with at least 1MW load in the Duke Energy Progress area who can reduce their load by a contracted amount during curtailment periods. These periods last no longer than eight hours and may occur during on- or off-peak hours. The total hours of curtailment periods will be no more than 400 per calendar year. On-peak hours occur on weekdays in the summer from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., and in the winter from 6 A.M. to 9 A.M. Customers face higher energy charges during these peak periods, but they can save money through shifting energy use to off-peak hours as well as discount hours, which run from 1 A.M. to 6 A.M. on all summer days and the periods of 1-3 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on all winter days. In addition, there are monthly credits of $4.90 per kW of demonstrated curtailable demand. Customers are notified a minimum of 30 minutes before a curtailment period.

Interruptible/Curtailable.hidden_program_name: Optional Time-of-day General Electric Service Rate
Interruptible/Curtailable.description: Customers are eligible for a number of interruptible rates from Montana-Dakota Utilities, including the Small Interruptible General Gas Service and Large Interruptible General Gas Service. Customers are given 10 minutes' notification before service is interrupted by the utility in exchange for lower monthly demand charges.

Green Mountain Power (GMP) offers a Curtailable Load Rider, which is available to commercial and industrial customers year-round who are able to curtail power when called upon by GMP. Customers are billed for their demand charge based on what their maximum load is during a curtailment event, allowing them to reduce their power draw at these times and be billed for the lower demand. Customers under this rider are notified of a curtailment event before 3 P.M. the previous day. Participants may be given only one hour's notice if GMP is experiencing emergency situations (e.g., unplanned generation outages or unusually high wholesale prices). Curtailment events last no more than four hours and can occur weekdays from 6 A.M. to 11 P.M. Participants must reduce their load by at least 500 kW or 25% of the customer's peak demand.

Rappahannock Electric Cooperative (REC) offers the Curtailable Service Rider (Schedule CS-1) to its commercial customers that are able to reduce their load by a minimum of 50 kW when called upon by REC. In exchange, customers will receive a monthly interruptible demand credit. Customers will receive notification of curtailment periods 5-15 minutes, or a mutually agreed upon time, depending on the time of day and the method of notification.

Puget Sound Energy's High Voltage Interruptible Service Rider (Schedule 46) allows PSE to interrupt power supply for commercial and industrial customers with billing demands greater than 4,400 kVa. In exchange, customers receive lower demand charges. Interruptions may occur between 8 A.M. to 12 P.M. and 5-8 P.M., Mondays through Saturdays. Interruptions will be limited to 210 hours per year.

Appalachian Power Company and Wheeling Power Company (both subsidiaries of American Electric Power) offer a negotiable interruptible rate (Contract Service—Interruptible Power), but only to their very large, high voltage customers (taking power at 138 kV and above).

Alliant Energy's Interruptible Program offers customers discounts for their willingness to reduce their power consumption to a firm level (by at least 200 kW) either immediately or with one hour's notice, depending on the option the customer chooses.

Madison Gas & Electric (MGE) offers interruptible rates for businesses with the ability to temporarily reduce their electricity usage. Two programs are available: IS-4: For businesses with at least 75 kW of curtailable demand and IS-3: For businesses that can curtail 500 kW or more of electricity use. MGE can interrupt service for up to 150 hours per year. In exchange for agreeing to these potential interruptions, customers receive bill credits every month, but there are penalties for customers who fail to comply with curtailment requests.

Wisconsin Public Service Corps offers an interruptible rider (CP-12). Participants contract for a 200 kW or greater load reduction (with curtailability up to 600 hours/year) subject to WPSC's determination of either economic or emergency conditions on the grid. In exchange, the customer receives reduced rates for its monthly peak demand. WSPC provides an additional credit of 40¢/kW per interruption for voluntary curtailments that exceed the program maximum of 600 hours. Customers receive notification of a curtailment event at least one hour before an event.

Xcel Energy customers can save on natural gas costs when they enroll in the Interruptible Gas Rate program. This program allows business customers to receive a one-hour notice from Xcel that they must go off the gas system and curtail their load completely during periods of peak gas demand, like cold winter mornings. A designated phone line connection to Xcel's telemetering device is required. Contact your Xcel Energy account manager or call 800-481-4700 for more information.

Rocky Mountain Power offers the Interruptible Service Pilot to businesses on Schedule 46 or 48T service. During interruptions , customers can earn credits by reducing their electricity usage. Rocky Mountain Power will notify participants at least 30 minutes before an event and can call up to 100 events per year, with a maximum of one event per day. Each event will last between 1 and 3 hours and can occur any day at any time. Customers receive $1 per kW of on-peak interruptible demand and $0.20 per kWh of interrupted energy.

Load Reduction Rate/Rider.description: Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company (OG&E) customers with a minimum load of 200 kW can take advantage of the Load Reduction Rider. Participants receive billing credits for their "subscribed curtailment load" (Subscription Credits) and load reduction (Performance Credits) during curtailment events. The Load Reduction on-peak period begins June 1st and ends September 30th. Curtailment events are called weekdays from 12 to 8 P.M. Customers can choose an event notification period of 30 minutes or 4 hours. Those who choose the 30-minute notification option will receive a 10% premium to the subscription credit. Curtailment hours are selected by customers, who can choose a curtailment limit of 40, 80, or 160 hours.

PG&E offers the Optional Binding Mandatory Curtailment Program, which provides customers with exemptions from rotating power outages if they can reduce their circuit load during Stage 3 emergencies. Participants must be able to reduce their load  by 15% below their established baseline load within 15 minutes of an alert and continue load reduction for the duration of the event. The penalty for failure to reduce as requested is $6.00 per kWh for energy use that exceeds an established baseline. Events can occur on any day (including holidays and weekends) without limitations to frequency and duration.

PG&E offers an automated demand response (ADR) program that provides free technical assistance and generous incentives to customers for installing automated DR equipment. Participation is open to customers enrolled in a qualifying DR or time-varying pricing option (such as PG&E's Peak Day Pricing ). ADR uses communication and control technology to automatically implement the customer's chosen pre-programmed load reductions, providing a fast and reliable way to respond to peak events, while still leaving the customer in complete control. The incentive is $200/kW (up to 75% of total equipment and installation costs) for measured and verifiable automated load reductions. Eligible equipment includes energy management systems and software, wired and wireless controls for lighting, HVAC, thermostats, motors, pumps and other equipment capable of receiving curtailment signals.

Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD) offers the PowerDirect Automated Demand Response program. Participating customers have automated controls installed on their energy management, lighting and/or HVAC systems that will automatically curtail system usage during peak periods. The program incentive is $7/kW per month and requires a one-year commitment. There are also generous incentives to cover the cost of installing the automated controls technology. Customers must be able to reduce usage for at least two consecutive hours during peak periods, and achieve at least 50% of their load reduction goal each event hour on eight of the called "conservation days," which take place between June 1 - September 30. The minimum load reduction needed to participate is 50kW and 5% of the peak period demand. Peak periods occur from 2 to 6 P.M. on weekdays. Curtailment events last between one and four hours. Customers will receive notification at least 30 minutes prior to a curtailment event, and often the day before.

Southern California Edison (SCE) offers the Scheduled Load Reduction Program (SLRP) to bundled-service customers whose average monthly demand is 100 kW or more. The program provides $0.10 per kWh on-bill credit for reducing load by at least 15% on pre scheduled days and times on weekdays from June 1 to September 30. Customers can choose one or more four-hour periods for load reduction, the options include: 8 A.M. to 12 P.M; 12 P.M. to 4 P.M. or 4 P.M. to 8 P.M.

SCE offers an automated demand response (Auto-DR) program which provide free technical assistance and generous incentives to customers for installing automated DR equipment. Participation is open to customers enrolled in a qualifying DR or time-varying pricing option (such as SCE's Critical Peak Pricing program). Auto-DR uses communication and control technology to automatically implement the customer's chosen pre-programmed load reductions, providing a fast and reliable way to respond to peak events, while still leaving the customer in complete control. The incentive is $200/kW (up to 75% of total equipment and installation costs) for measured and verifiable automated load reductions. Eligible equipment includes energy management systems and software, wired and wireless controls for lighting, HVAC, thermostats, motors, pumps and other equipment capable of receiving curtailment signals.

Through the Peak Day Partners (PDP) program, Xcel Energy customers who can reduce demand preferably by 500 kW or more (though smaller nominations are accepted) can receive credit for reducing their load during peak event times. Events usually occur on weekday afternoons in the summer (June 1 – September 30). The day before events, participants are contacted to determine willingness to reducing their electricity load and to establish a purchase price for their energy reduction. They can then accept or decline Xcel's offer, or provide a counter offer. Once the offer is accepted, participants are committed to a minimum load reduction for each hour of the buyback period relative to a "baseline load profile" determined from the five highest energy consumption days within the last ten non-holiday weekdays. Remuneration is provided in the form of a bill credit or separate payment.

Eversource offers its Variable Peak Pricing (VPP) rider to customers on a time-of-day rate. Customers receiving service under this rider pay a variable price for electricity as off-peak power adjusts monthly and on-peak (weekdays, 12 to 8 P.M.) rates vary by day (with notice provided the day prior). This allows customers to shift their electricity consumption from on-peak to off-peak hours and reduce energy costs. Customers interested in receiving service under this rider must contact the company to request service.

Eversource offers a voluntary Electric Vehicle Rate Program to any customers with a level 2 or level 3 charging station whose load is separately metered and available for use by the public. Rates for electric service provided under this rider will be determined in accordance with the Company's general service rate schedule. For more information visit the FAQs page.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) offers its Demand Resources programs, which provide payments to electricity users for load reductions (of as little as 100 kW), either by reducing usage or operating on-site generation during periods of high demand or prices. Customers may participate in the programs through any participating member ("market participant") of the New England Power Pool, such as a utility company, power marketer, competitive energy supplier, or independent curtailment service provider (CSP). A market participant is allowed to aggregate load to reach the quantity qualification limit, so interested customers with less than 100 kW to offer may want to contact their utility or other eligible party.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has a Forward Capacity Market (FCM). The FCM allows customers to bid their load reduction capabilities—whether constant (such as an indoor lighting retrofit project), seasonal (such as a new energy-efficient chiller plant), or dispatchable (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output)—into a capacity auction that allows demand-side resources to compete with supply-side ones. Bids that are accepted are paid the auction clearing price. These auctions take place annually for commitment periods three years in the future (though the qualification process begins roughly a year before the auction). Interested facilities should contact a market participant regarding the auction schedule; in addition, market participants may have unfilled capacity commitments ahead of the next auction.

Delmarva's Hourly Priced Service Rider (Rider HPS), is a real time pricing rate and is the default for large (>1,000 kW peak) customers that do not contract for third-party electric supply. The rate is also available for general service customers who meet the applicable eligibility requirements discussed in Delmarva's Electric Tariff Document.

PJM's Capacity Performance program allows demand resources to participate in PJM's Reliability Pricing Model forward capacity market via an aggregator (any existing PJM member, such as their utility, a third-party electricity supplier, or a specialty curtailment service provider, CSP). Participants pledge to either reduce their load by a specified amount (guaranteed load drop, GLD), or to a specific kW level (known as firm service level, FSL), within one or two hours of an event notification. Load reductions are mandatory, lasting up to six hours per event. While events can be called any day of the year, some CSPs offer a summer-only option (pairing those resources with winter-only ones at their disposal). Penalties for non-compliance are substantial. Remuneration is based on the results of the annual RPM capacity auctions in various PJM regions. Remuneration levels for the 2024-25 PJM year (which runs from June 1st, 2024 to May 31st, 2025) are in the $24,000 per MW range for Delaware customers. Participants are also eligible to receive energy payments for actual reductions, if and when the program is called.

PJM's Economic Load Response program allows electricity users to provide load reductions in exchange for a payment based on hourly wholesale electricity prices. Participation is fully voluntary. Customers start by submitting load reduction bids (through their CSP) of at least 100 kW into the day-ahead energy market. Participants whose bids are accepted are paid for their load reductions based upon the day-ahead, hourly electricity market prices (the day-ahead "locational marginal price," or LMP). Reductions are figured based on a customer baseline load (CBL), which is essentially the average loads for the same hours in four of the facility's previous non-responding days. Regardless of which type of firm it is, the CSP will generally offer to split the revenues with the customer at a pre-determined percentage.

PJM allows energy efficiency projects to participate in its forward capacity markets, based on the Reliability Pricing Model. To be eligible, EE projects must reduce load continuously by at least 100 kW during peak summer hours. This load reduction can be bid into PJM's annual (for three years in advance) and "residual" (nearer-term) capacity auctions, and if selected will receive the auction clearing price. Interested customers can participate through contractors such as energy service companies (conducting ESPCs) or utilities (executing UESCs) at their sites

Florida Power and Light (FPL) offers the Commercial/Industrial Demand Reduction Rider to commercial or industrial customers that agree to allow FPL to control at least 200 kW of the customer's load. The load must be controllable for at least three months during the summer (April through October). Customers will receive a monthly credit of $8.70 per kW based on the customer's energy usage. At least one hour's notice will be provided before load control events, except in emergency situations. Events will last up to 6 hours and will occur no more than 25 times per year. Customers participating in the On Call® Savings Program are not eligible for this rider. This rider is offered to customers in all areas served by the utility.
Ameren offers its commercial/industrial customers the Hourly Supply Service (Rider HSS), an hourly priced option based on the relevant MISO delivery point.

ComEd's Voluntary Load Reduction (VLR) program pays customers for responding to individual load reduction requests of generally two to eight hours with at least one hour notice. Participants are notified of the payment level in advance of each event and are guaranteed at least $0.25 per kWh for their reduced usage. The program is open to any customer in ComEd's service territory, although electricity generation customers of ComEd are eligible for greater incentives. To participate, a customer must have an interval meter and be able to curtail at least 10 kW of peak load. Participation in curtailment events is voluntary.

MidAmerican Energy offers the Curtailment Service Rider (Rider CS) to customers under the General Service, Large General Service, Substation Service and Individual Customer Rates who are able to curtail at least 200 kW when provided notice by the utility. Customers have the option to participate only during the summer period (June through September) and receive a credit of $30/kW, or participate year-round and receive a credit of $60/kW.

Duke Energy customers with an average monthly demand greater than 15 kW can enroll in the Load Management Rider (Rider LM). This billing mechanism allows customers to be assessed for only their peak power draw during the company's peak period hours (i.e., the "coincident" peak), such that off-peak demand is not penalized. This rate is tailored for sites, such as those with thermal energy storage (TES), that can shift substantial load to off-peak periods. Summer off-peak hours are from 8 P.M. to 11 A.M., Monday to Friday; winter off-peak hours are from 2 to 5 P.M. and 9 P.M. to 9 A.M. during weekdays. All hours on weekends and holidays are considered off-peak, as well.

The Peak Load Management (PLM) program from Duke Energy offers negotiated incentives for small- to mid-sized customers to reduce load during the utility's peak periods. The Rider PLM rate is available to customers served under Rate DS, DT, DP, TT, or special contracts, whose billing period 15-minute demands are less than 500 kW. The specific hours for the PLM service option will be mutually agreed upon between the customer and company and specified in the service agreement. Customers can choose to participate and receive energy bill credits through by 1) reducing their demand down to a specific load, 2)  reducing their energy usage below their baseline, or 3) selling the output of any customer-owned self generation to the utility when notified of a peak load period.

PJM's Capacity Performance program allows demand resources to participate in PJM's Reliability Pricing Model forward capacity market via an aggregator (any existing PJM member, such as their utility, a third-party electricity supplier, or a specialty curtailment service provider, CSP). Participants are also eligible to receive energy payments for actual reductions, if and when the program is called.

Delmarva Power's Non-Residential Direct Load Control Rider allows participating customers to let the utility install, own, and maintain either a smart thermostat or a remotely controlled switch(es) that will cycle on and off the customer's central air conditioner or heat pump. Direct load control events can occur from June through October. Customers receive a one-time enrollment installment credit of $80 and an annual credit of $80.

Load Reduction Rate/Rider.description: PEPCO offers the Master-Metered ("MM") Direct Load Control Rider, where a master-metered customer allows PEPCO to install direct load control devices or smart thermostats on the participant's central air conditioners or heat pumps. Customers can choose from 50%, 75%, or 100% cycling options. Customers receive a one-time installation credit ranging from $15-$30 and an annual bill credit of $15-$30 dependent on the chosen cycling option.

Customers can participate in Eversource's Demand Response programs, either through a curtailment service provider (CSP) or independently. Customers enrolled in the Summer Targeted Dispatch program (June through September) get remunerated for curtailing load at $35/kW, with an additional weekend bonus of $10/kW if the event happens to fall on a weekend. Load reduction events occur weekdays from 3 to 8 P.M. Customers enrolled in the Daily Dispatch program get remunerated at $200/kW in the summer as well as the weekend bonus. There are typically 30 to 60 events called per summer with each event lasting between 2-3 hours. Notifications for load reduction events are sent at least 24 hours prior. Customers can get started by contacting connectedsolutions@eversource.com.

Customers can participate in National Grid's ConnectedSolutions programs, either through a curtailment service provider (CSP) or independently. Customers enrolled in the Summer Targeted Dispatch program (June through September) get remunerated for curtailing load at $35/kW. Load reduction events occur weekdays from 3 to 8 P.M. Customers enrolled in the Daily Dispatch program get remunerated at $200/kW in the summer. There are typically 30 to 60 events called per summer with each event lasting between 2-3 hours. Notifications for load reduction events are sent at least 24 hours prior. Customers can contact their Curtailment Service Provider to learn more or get started.

Unitil offers its ConnectedSolutions  program to customers that are able to reduce their peak demand during the summer (June through September). Customers are remunerated at a minimum of $18/kW. There are typically eight load reduction events per season, lasting no more than three hours. Customers can call 1-844-276-9371 or email ConnectedSolutions@CPowerEnergyManagement.com to enroll.

Wisconsin Public Service Corporation (WPSC) offers a Direct Control Rider (Cg-DCM) to small commercial and industrial customers in Michigan, through which it remunerates customers up to $8 per unit per summer month for the ability to control their packaged air conditioners, and $3 per month (throughout the year) for controlling electric storage water heaters (40 gallons and above).

Otter Tail Power Company offers the Off-Peak Electric Vehicle Rider to customers with electric vehicle chargers. Participants receive heavily discounted electric charging service during the authorized period from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M. each day, though are penalized for charging outside of those hours.

Otter Tail Power Company programs provides two money-saving options for customers with separately metered water heaters through the Water Heating Control Rider. For the water heating credit option, customers receive an $8-10 credit on their monthly bill in exchange for permitting the utility to directly control their electric water heaters for up to 14 hours per day. For the Controlled Service Water Heater Rate option, customers can take advantage of a lower rate (about 25% lower than standard electric rates) in exchange for connecting their water heater to a separately metered off-peak electric service. For both options, water heaters may be controlled for up to 14 hours per day. This rate may be combined with rebates for new electric water heaters.

Evergy's Voluntary Load Reduction Rider allows customers with a peak demand of 500 kW in the last year to receive bill credits in exchange for reducing load upon the request of the company at any time during the year. Credit values per kWh of energy reduction vary and will be disclosed prior to an event.

The Market Based Demand Response Program from Evergy offers qualified Business Demand Response Program customers the additional opportunity to participate in load reduction during high price periods and declared emergency events in the wholesale Southwest Power Pool (SPP) energy market. Through this program, customers can receive compensation for load reduction through SPP settlement payments.

In partnership with CPower, Montana-Dakota Utilities offers its Demand Response Resources Program for commercial and industrial customers who agree to curtail non-critical load during demand response events initiated by the utility. Load response events may be called at any time throughout the year. Customers enrolled in the program are not obligated to curtail load for longer than four hours in a single day, or more than 50 hours per year. Customers are notified 60 minutes prior to the load response event via email, phone, and/or text. Participants receive capacity payments based on the amount of their curtailment commitment (kW) and energy payments based on the amount of energy reduced (kWh) during actual events. The minimum load reduction is approximately 25 kW. Participants receive compensation on a quarterly basis via check or ACH through CPower, a third-party demand response aggregator. Contact CPower at 1-844-276-9371 for more information.

Nebraska Public Power District (NPPD) offers the Demand Waiver Program Rider for customers with on-site generation. Customers can take advantage of a reduction in demand charges in exchange for reducing load by at least 100 kW during on-peak hours that have not been waived by the utility.  On-site generation nameplate capacity must not exceed 500 kW.

Nebraska Public Power District (NPPD) offers the Off-Peak Service Rider, which provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours. On-peak hours for the period of October through May are defined as 8 A.M. to 10 P.M, Monday through Saturday. On-peak hours for June through September are defined as 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., Monday through Saturday.

The Market-Based Rate Rider from Nebraska Public Power District (NPPD) is for customers who have a minimum monthly demand of 6,250 kW and would like to enter into a rate agreement with NPPD that is based on wholesale power rates from the Southwest Power Pool (SPP).

Omaha Public Power District offers the General Service/Large General Service Curtailment rider to customers willing to mandatorily curtail a minimum of 100 kW (with minimum 20% reduction of customer load) or 500 kW (without restrictions) of demand during called events. Capacity curtailment periods may occur from June 1 through September 15, 12 to 10 P.M., Monday through Friday, and can be called throughout the year. Incentive amounts vary from $4.67-$4.96 per kW based on the minimum demand. Customers will be notified at least four hours in advance of a load curtailment event. Customers will face a non-compliance charge if they fail to reduce load by the contracted amount during an event.

NV Energy offers Electric Vehicle Rate Riders to customers with electric vehicle chargers. Participants receive savings for charging their vehicles during the Special EV Recharge Period (12:01 A.M. - 8:00 A.M.)

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) offers its Demand Resources programs, which provide payments to electricity users for load reductions (of as little as 100 kW), either by reducing usage or operating on-site generation during periods of high demand or prices. Customers may participate in the programs through any participating member ("market participant") of the New England Power Pool, such as a utility company, power marketer, competitive energy supplier, or independent curtailment service provider (CSP). A market participant is allowed to aggregate load to reach the quantity qualification limit, so interested customers with less than 100 kW to offer may want to contact their utility or other eligible party.

The Independent System Operator New England Inc. (ISO-NE) has a Forward Capacity Market (FCM). The FCM allows customers to bid their load reduction capabilities—whether constant (such as an indoor lighting retrofit project), seasonal (such as a new energy-efficient chiller plant), or dispatchable (such as demand management or an on-site generator with controllable output)—into a capacity auction that allows demand-side resources to compete with supply-side ones. Bids that are accepted are paid the auction clearing price. These auctions take place annually for commitment periods three years in the future (though the qualification process begins roughly a year before the auction). Interested facilities should contact a market participant regarding the auction schedule; in addition, market participants may have unfilled capacity commitments ahead of the next auction.

Unitil offers its ConnectedSolutions program to customers who are able to reduce their peak demand during the summer (June through September). Customers enrolled are remunerated at a minimum of $25/kW in the summer. There are one to eight load reduction events per season, lasting no more than three hours.

Orange and Rockland (O&R) offers its C&I customers the Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) a demand response program that offers customers incentives to temporarily reduce their electric usage when requested by O&R. Events can be called Monday-Friday and customers are provided a notice of at least 21 hours. Customers must maintain a minimum four-hour load reduction per event. Customers receive a monthly reservation payment of  $3/kW and an additional $0.50/kWh performance payment during events. Customers who are able to reduce their demand by 50 kW or more can apply directly with the utility. A voluntary participation option is available as well, customers enrolled in this option will only receive payments if they reduce energy at O&R's request and will receive $1/kWh reduction.

Orange and Rockland (O&R) offers its C&I customers the Distribution Load Relief Program (DLRP) a demand response program that offers customers incentives to temporarily reduce their electric usage when requested by O&R. Events can be called from 6 A.M.-12 A.M. any day of the week and customers are provide a notification of two hours or less. Customers must maintain a minimum four-hour load reduction per event. Customers in the Tier 1 areas receive a monthly reservation payment of  $3/kW and customers in the Tier 2 Areas receive a monthly reservation payment of $5/kW. Customers in both areas receive an additional $0.50/kWh performance payment during events. Customers who are able to reduce their demand by 50 kW or more can apply directly with the utility. A voluntary participation option is available as well, customers enrolled in this option will only receive payments if they reduce energy at O&R's request and will receive $1/kWh reduction.

PJM's Capacity Performance program allows demand resources to participate in PJM's Reliability Pricing Model forward capacity market via an aggregator (any existing PJM member, such as their utility, a third-party electricity supplier, or a specialty curtailment service provider, CSP). Participants pledge to either reduce their load by a specified amount (guaranteed load drop, GLD), or to a specific kW level (known as firm service level, FSL), within one or two hours of an event notification. Load reductions are mandatory lasting up to six hours per event. While events can be called any day of the year, some CSPs offer a summer-only option (pairing those resources with winter-only ones at their disposal). Penalties for non-compliance are substantial. Remuneration is based on the results of the annual RPM capacity auctions in various PJM regions. Remuneration levels for the 2024-25 PJM year (which runs from June 1st, 2024 to May 31st, 2025) are in the $18,000 - $20,000 per MW range for most New Jersey customers. Participants are also eligible to receive energy payments for actual reductions, if and when the program is called.

PJM's Economic Load Response program allows electricity users to provide load reductions in exchange for a payment based on hourly wholesale electricity prices. Participation is fully voluntary. Customers start by submitting load reduction bids (through their CSP) of at least 100 kW into the day-ahead energy market. Participants whose bids are accepted are paid for their load reductions based upon the day-ahead, hourly electricity market prices (the day-ahead "locational marginal price," or LMP). Reductions are figured based on a customer baseline load (CBL), which is essentially the average loads for the same hours in four of the facility's previous non-responding days. Regardless of which type of firm it is, the CSP will generally offer to split the revenues with the customer at a pre-determined percentage.

PJM allows energy efficiency projects to participate in its forward capacity markets, based on the Reliability Pricing Model. To be eligible, EE projects must reduce load continuously by at least 100 kW during peak summer hours. This load reduction can be bid into PJM's annual (for three years in advance) and "residual" (nearer-term) capacity auctions, and if selected will receive the auction clearing price. Interested customers can participate through contractors such as energy service companies (conducting ESPCs) or utilities (executing UESCs) at their sites

Customers with load-shifting capability can take advantage of ConEd's Day-Ahead Hourly Pricing (Rider M) rate, under which all power is charged at the day-ahead price. By gauging day-ahead pricing, customers can plan their load reduction strategies around high-price periods and, in turn, benefit from shifting load to lower-priced periods.

ConEd customers can enroll in the Direct Load Control Program (Rider L), which allows the utility to install a control device on customers' central air conditioning units and remotely control the equipment when load reduction events are called. Customers can receive a control device from ConEd or enroll their own device through a service provider. Customers receive a sign-up payment of $85. Starting with the third summer (May 1 - September 30) of participation, customers will be eligible for an annual incentive payment of $25.

Through the Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) National Grid offers its New York electricity customers incentives for reducing their electricity usage during peak periods. Two enrollment options are available, one voluntary (for which payments are made only for called event performance) and one, the more lucrative "reservation payment" option, in which customers are also remunerated ($2.75/kW each month) for their commitment to respond to events. Customers under the reservation payment option receive a performance payment $0.18/kWh for planned events and $0.22/kWh for unplanned events while customers under the voluntary option receive a performance payment of $0.16/kWh for planning events and $0.19/kWh for unplanning events. Customers can participate directly if they can reduce by 50 kW or more, or through participating curtailment service providers (CSPs), which can often help find additional load reduction opportunities. Enrollment for this program closes June 1.

Load Reduction Rate/Rider.hidden_program_name: Installed Capacity Special Case Resource Program
Load Reduction Rate/Rider.description: NYISO offers the Installed Capacity ("ICAP") Special Case Resource (SCR) program which provides financial incentives for electricity consumers to reduce their electricity consumption or operate on-site generation to cut their draw from the electric grid during periods of reserve shortage or reliability need. The minimum offered load reduction to the wholesale market is 100 kW and can be achieved by aggregating multiple consumers within a load zone. Curtailment events can last up to four hours or more (however participants must respond for the lesser of the event duration or four hours). NYISO provides two-hour notice of events as well as day-ahead advisories. Participants receive two separate payment streams: a capacity payment and an energy payment. The capacity payment is based on their committed load reduction (specifically, it's accredited value in the NYISO's ICAP market, 64% for 2024, based on the accreditation of a 4-hour storage resource). This accreditation value is subject to change on an annual basis. The energy payment is for their actual cuts during events. Participants face non-compliance penalties if they do not curtail their committed amount when called by NYISO. Individual customers may participate through an authorized "responsible interface party" (RIP), which coordinates transactions with NYISO or can act as their own RIP, and cannot commit the same resources in both the Emergency Demand Response Program and SCR.

Commercial customers with a billed demand greater than or equal to 300 kW in any two months are automatically enrolled in NYSEG's day-ahead hourly pricing rate. By gauging day-ahead pricing, customers can plan their load reduction strategies around high-price periods and, in turn, benefit from shifting load to lower-priced periods. For more information on this rate, contact NYSEG directly.

Orange and Rockland (O&R) offers its C&I customers the Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) a demand response program that offers customers incentives to temporarily reduce their electric usage when requested by O&R. Events can be called Monday-Friday and customers are provided a notice of at least 21 hours. Customers must maintain a minimum four-hour load reduction per event. Customers enrolled in the reservation payment option receive a monthly reservation payment of  $3/kW and an additional $0.50/kWh performance payment during events. Customers who are able to reduce their demand by 50 kW or more can apply directly with the utility. Enrollment for the reservation payment option closes May 2nd 2024. A voluntary participation option is available as well, customers enrolled in this option will only receive payments if they reduce energy at O&R's request and will receive $1/kWh reduction. Enrollment in the voluntary participation option is available until September 30th 2024.

Orange and Rockland (O&R) offers its C&I customers the Distribution Load Relief Program (DLRP) a demand response program that offers customers incentives to temporarily reduce their electric usage when requested by O&R. Events can be called from 6 A.M.-12 A.M. any day of the week and customers are provide a notification of two hours or less. Customers must maintain a minimum four-hour load reduction per event. Customers in the Tier 1 areas receive a monthly reservation payment of  $3/kW and customers in the Tier 2 Areas receive a monthly reservation payment of $5/kW. Customers in both areas receive an additional $0.50/kWh performance payment during events. Customers who are able to reduce their demand by 50 kW or more can apply directly with the utility. A voluntary participation option is available as well, customers enrolled in this option will only receive payments if they reduce energy at O&R's request and will receive $1/kWh reduction.

PSE&G Long Island offers its Commercial System Relief Program from May 1st to September 30th. Load reduction events last approximately four hours. Customers receive reservation payments of $8/kW if also participating in the Distribution Load Relief Program, and performance payments of $0.25/kWh. Customers can participate through eligible curtailment service providers (CSPs), which can often help find additional load reduction opportunities, or enroll directly if they guarantee a minimum of 50 kW in load reduction per event. Notifications to load reduction events for CRSP customers must be a minimum of 21 hours in advance.

Rochester Gas and Electric (RG&E) offers its C&I customers the Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) a demand response program that offers customers incentives to temporarily reduce their electric usage when requested. The program runs from May 1st to September 30th. Load reduction events last approximately four hours. Customers can choose either the voluntary performance option or the reservation payment option. Both programs offer a performance payment rate of $0.50/kWh. The reservation payment option remunerates customers at $4.25/kW per month (or $4.50 if five or more events are called). The enrollment deadline for the Reservation Payment Option is May 1 2024, the Voluntary Participation Option enrollment deadline is September 30, 2024.

All SC8 and SC14 customers are automatically enrolled in RGE's day-ahead hourly pricing rate. By gauging day-ahead pricing, customers can plan their load reduction strategies around high-price periods and, in turn, benefit from shifting load to lower-priced periods. For more information on this rate, contact NYSEG directly.

PJM's Capacity Performance program allows demand resources to participate in PJM's Reliability Pricing Model forward capacity market via an aggregator (any existing PJM member, such as their utility, a third-party electricity supplier, or a specialty curtailment service provider, CSP). Participants pledge to either reduce their load by a specified amount (guaranteed load drop, GLD), or to a specific kW level (known as firm service level, FSL), within one or two hours of an event notification. Load reductions are mandatory lasting up to six hours per event. While events can be called any day of the year, some CSPs offer a summer-only option (pairing those resources with winter-only ones at their disposal). Penalties for non-compliance are substantial. Remuneration is based on the results of the annual RPM capacity auctions in various PJM regions. Remuneration levels for the 2024-25 PJM year (which runs from June 1st, 2024 to May 31st, 2025) is approximately $10,000 per MW range for customers in PJM's northeastern North Carolina footprint. Participants are also eligible to receive energy payments for actual reductions, if and when the program is called.

This load reduction can be bid into PJM's annual (for three years in advance) and "residual" (nearer-term) capacity auctions, and if selected will receive the auction clearing price. Interested customers can participate through contractors such as energy service companies (conducting ESPCs) or utilities (executing UESCs) at their sites

Montana-Dakota Utilities offers a Demand Response Resources Program for commercial and industrial customers who agree to curtail non-critical load during demand response events initiated by the utility. Load response events may be called at any time throughout the year, but participants are not obligated to curtail load for longer than four hours in a single day, or more than 50 hours per year. The utility notifies customers at least 60 minutes prior to load response events via email, phone, and/or text. Participants receive capacity payments based on the amount of their curtailment commitment (kW) and energy payments based on the amount of energy reduced (kWh) during actual events. The minimum load reduction is approximately 25 kW. Participants receive compensation on a quarterly basis via check or ACH through CPower, a third-party demand response aggregator (aka curtailment service provider, CSP). Contact CPower at 1-844-276-9371 for more information.

Duke Energy customers can participate in the Load Management Rider (Rider LM). This billing mechanism allows customers to be assessed for only their peak power draw during the company's peak period hours (i.e., the "coincident" peak), such that off-peak demand spikes are not penalized. This rate is tailored for sites that can shift substantial load to off-peak periods. Summer off-peak hours are from 8 P.M. to 11 A.M., Monday to Friday (June 1 to September 30); winter off-peak hours are from 2 to 5 P.M. and 9 P.M. to 9 A.M. during weekdays. All hours on weekends and holidays are considered off-peak, as well.

Duke Energy customers can enroll in the voluntary Peak Load Management Program (Rider PLM) to reduce their costs by shifting their electric usage away from peak periods (from 11AM to 8PM, Monday to Friday, during the summer, and 7 A.M. to 1 P.M., Monday to Friday, during winter).

Remuneration levels for the 2024-25 PJM year (which runs from June 1st, 2025 to May 31st, 2025) are in the $10,000 - $20,000 per MW range for Ohio customers. Participants are also eligible to receive energy payments for actual reductions, if and when the program is called.

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company's performance-based Load Reduction program offers financial incentives to commercial and industrial customers that curtail their electrical load when notified by OG&E. Customers subscribe to an amount of demand reduction, and if they reduce their usage during a called event, they receive a discount.

Duquesne also offers medium-large and industrial customers a Day-Ahead Hourly Price  rider for customers that have a monthly billing demand of 200 kW or greater. Energy charges are provided at the day-ahead PJM locational marginal prices based on the customer's real time metered hourly load.

In partnership with CPower, Montana-Dakota Utilities offers its Demand Response Resources Program for commercial and industrial customers who agree to curtail non-critical load during demand response events initiated by the utility. Load response events may be called at any time throughout the year, but participants are not obligated to curtail load for longer than four hours in a single day, or more than 50 hours per year. The utility notifies customers at least 60 minutes prior to load response events via email, phone, and/or text. Participants receive capacity payments based on the amount of their curtailment commitment (kW) and energy payments based on the amount of energy reduced (kWh) during actual events. The minimum load reduction is approximately 25 kW. Participants receive compensation on a quarterly basis via check or ACH through CPower, a third-party demand response aggregator (aka curtailment service provider, CSP). Contact CPower at 1-844-276-9371 for more information.

Austin Energy customers looking to shave costs can enroll in the Load Shifting Voltage Discount Rider program. This program rewards customers who can shift at least 30% of their usual peak electricity usage away from the high-demand window of 3 pm to 6 pm weekdays by utilizing storage solutions like thermal or battery systems. By doing so, they'll receive a discount on charges determined by the highest 15-minute power draw during that specific on-peak period. However, it's important to remember that the total energy used (kWh) is still charged based on all your consumption during the separate on-peak window of 7 am to 10 pm weekdays.

El Paso Electric offers its Texas Load Management Program to customers who can curtail at least 100 kW per participating site during the summer (June 1 through September 30) with one-hour notice. Customers receive a maximum of $48/kW for the average kW reduction for all curtailments (see program manual for additional payment details). Up to nine peak events per year, lasting up to four continuous hours each, may be called on summer weekdays from 1-7 P.M. (MDT). Participants are required to demonstrate load reduction capability by participating in one scheduled curtailment at the beginning of the program period.

ERCOT's Emergency Response Service (ERS) program allows qualified loads and generators (including aggregators of loads and generators) to make themselves available for curtailment (on 10- to 30-minute notice) in an electric grid emergency. ERS is designed to decrease the likelihood of the need for involuntary load shedding, such as rolling blackouts. Customers bid to provide load reductions. Note this program is aimed solely at alleviating emergency (as opposed to high price) conditions on the ERCOT grid.

Texas-New Mexico Power Company's (TNMP) Load Management Program offers incentives of up to $40 per kW for curtailing at least 40 kW for a maximum of 18 hours total. For a given period (summer or winter), customers commit to a maximum of four unscheduled curtailments, each no more than four hours' duration. Summer period curtailments can occur from June 1 to September 30, between 1 and 7 P.M. on weekdays, while winter period curtailments can occur any time of day from December 1 to February 28. Customers receive notification at least 30 minutes prior to curtailment events. Payment is based on amount of load curtailed; customers are not required to curtail a specific amount and there are no penalties for non-delivery of load reduction. Applications are evaluated on a first-come, first-served basis. Participants must be able to demonstrate load reduction capability by participating in a scheduled curtailment event of one to two hours.

Rocky Mountain Power's Cool Keeper program provides a nominal annual bill credit in exchange for allowing the utility to install at no cost a web-programmable thermostat or digital control unit (DCU). On selected peak demand weekdays from May 1 through September 30 excluding holidays between the hours of 2 and 9 P.M., the utility will coordinate load reduction for participating air conditioner units. The utility will dispatch Cool Keeper events no more than 100 hours per year and events are limited to four hours per day. This program is available to customers along the Wasatch Front only.

Green Mountain Power offers the Load Response Rider, in which commercial and industrial customers curtail at least 500 KW during times of peak demand on the grid in exchange for having their monthly demand charge be based on their peak power draw during the previous non-event day. Customers are notified of a curtailment event at least one hour prior. Curtailment events last no more than five hours and occur no more than eight days per month. Curtailment events can occur at any hour of the day.

(ISO-NE) offers its Demand Resources programs, which provide payments to electricity users for load reductions (of as little as 100 kW), either by reducing usage or operating on-site generation during periods of high demand or prices. Puget Sound Energy's Voluntary Load Curtailment Rider (Schedule 93) allows utility bill savings for commercial customers who reduce energy consumption during curtailment periods determined by the utility. Customers must be able to curtail 500 kW of load over a minimum of one hour and will receive bill credits based on the curtailed energy.

Puget Sound Energy's Business Demand Response Program, in partnership with AutoGrid and Enel, provides incentives to commercial and industrial customers who can limit electricity usage for short periods of time. Customers develop a custom curtailment plan with the utility based on their historical energy use data. Incentives are based on the committed load reduction capacity and the average participation in events during a given season.
