Customers start by submitting load reduction bids (through their CSP) of at least 100 kW into the day-ahead energy market. Participants whose bids are accepted are paid for their load reductions based upon the day-ahead, hourly electricity market prices (the day-ahead "locational marginal price," or LMP). Reductions are figured based on a customer baseline load (CBL), which is essentially the average loads for the same hours in four of the facility's previous non-responding days. Regardless of which type of firm it is, the CSP will generally offer to split the revenues with the customer at a pre-determined percentage.

PJM allows energy efficiency projects to participate in its forward capacity markets, based on the Reliability Pricing Model. To be eligible, EE projects must reduce load continuously by at least 100 kW during peak summer hours. This load reduction can be bid into PJM's annual (for three years in advance) and "residual" (nearer-term) capacity auctions, and if selected will receive the auction clearing price. Interested customers can participate through contractors such as energy service companies (conducting ESPCs) or utilities (executing UESCs) at their sites

PJM's Capacity Performance program allows demand resources to participate in PJM's Reliability Pricing Model forward capacity market via an aggregator (any existing PJM member, such as their utility, a third-party electricity supplier, or a specialty curtailment service provider, CSP). Participants pledge to either reduce their load by a specified amount (guaranteed load drop, GLD), or to a specific kW level (known as firm service level, FSL), within one or two hours of an event notification. Load reductions are mandatory lasting up to six hours per event. While events can be called any day of the year, some CSPs offer a summer-only option (pairing those resources with winter-only ones at their disposal). Penalties for non-compliance are substantial. Remuneration is based on the results of the annual RPM capacity auctions in various PJM regions. Remuneration levels for the 2024–25 PJM year (which runs from June 1, 2024, to May 31, 2025) are in the $8,000 – $12,000 per MW range for most West Virginia customers. Participants are also eligible to receive energy payments for actual reductions, if and when the program is called.

PJM's Economic Load Response program allows electricity users to provide load reductions in exchange for a payment based on hourly wholesale electricity prices. Participation is fully voluntary. Customers start by submitting load reduction bids (through their CSP) of at least 100 kW into the day-ahead energy market. Participants whose bids are accepted are paid for their load reductions based upon the day-ahead, hourly electricity market prices (the day-ahead "locational marginal price," or LMP). Reductions are figured based on a customer baseline load (CBL), which is essentially the average loads for the same hours in four of the facility's previous non-responding days. Regardless of which type of firm it is, the CSP will generally offer to split the revenues with the customer at a pre-determined percentage.

PJM allows energy efficiency projects to participate in its forward capacity markets, based on the Reliability Pricing Model. To be eligible, EE projects must reduce load continuously by at least 100 kW during peak summer hours. This load reduction can be bid into PJM's annual (for three years in advance) and "residual" (nearer-term) capacity auctions, and if selected will receive the auction clearing price. Interested customers can participate through contractors such as energy service companies (conducting ESPCs) or utilities (executing UESCs) at their sites

Critical Peak Pricing.description: Xcel Energy offers a Critical Peak Pricing option to customers who are able to cut their loads for up to four hours between 12-8 P.M. on up to 15 non-holiday weekdays per year. Customers participating in this program receive a discounted demand charge that can save them 5-10% of their total electricity bill. During events, though, electricity prices are many times higher than usual. Customers are notified by the utility at least 22 hours prior to a critical peak event. The contract term to participate in this program is a minimum of 12 months.

Delmarva Power's Peak Energy Savings Credit program is a variant of "critical peak pricing." It allows small commercial customers to respond to alerts (via phone, text, or e-mail) the day before an event indicating that the following day will be a program day and identifying the peak hours (generally between 12 and 8 P.M. on weekdays, June to September). Customers can then react (there's no penalty for not responding) by cutting their loads during the events. Remuneration is set by actual performance relative to the average of a customer's three highest peaks in the prior 30 days. Customers will receive a credit of $1.25 for every kWh they reduce their energy usage below their baseline on Peak Savings Days. No enrollment is necessary.

Critical Peak Pricing.hidden_program_name: EV Plug in Electric Vehicle Rate
Critical Peak Pricing.description: Liberty Utility customers can enroll in the EV Plug in Electric Vehicle Rate option, which offers price differentiation between on- and off-peak hours for charging plug-in electric vehicles (EVs). The rates are seasonal with a winter (November through April) and summer (May through October) season. Off-peak hours are from 8 P.M. to 8 A.M.; mid-peak hours are from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday through Friday (except holidays); mid-peak hours are 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays; and "critical peak" hours (when rates are highest) take place from 3 to 8 P.M. Monday through Friday (except holidays).

Variable Peak Pricing.description: Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company's (OG&E's) SmartHours program offers two rates for encouraging shifts away from peak usage (2-7 p.m., Monday-Friday on non holidays). The Variable Peak Pricing (VPP) rate, also known as SmartHours Hourly. allows customers to be credited or charged based upon day-ahead hourly energy price. Peak hours are based on ranges in hourly prices, characterized as low, medium, high or critical, with escalating prices at each level, up to $0.49/kWh. The SmartHours Fixed rate charges $0.23/kWh during the peak period, compared to a non-peak price of $0.06/kWh.

Other Rate Type.description: Alaska Electric Light and Power offers two special rates for electric vehicle drivers classified as small commercial users. Rate 93 is available to drivers who install their own chargers or rent chargers, and offers reduced rates for charging between 10 P.M. and 5 A.M. For commercial customers, the energy charge is $0.0600/kWh during the off-peak season of June to October (AEL&P is a "winter-peaking" utility) and $0.0677 during peak season (November to May). Rate 94 offers the same reduced rates to customers who rent 240 volt charging equipment from the utility. For this rate, there is a monthly equipment rental charge of $10.74.

Other Rate Type.hidden_program_name: Time-of-week price plan for pumping service
Other Rate Type.description: Salt River Project (SRP) offers a time-of-week price plan for water pumping services to municipal water utilities and commercial agricultural production, with higher rates for summer and summer peak seasons than the winter season. This applies to pump facilities with their own meter. In this plan, participants have designated no-pump days during the summer and summer peak seasons (May 1 through Oct 31) from the hours of noon to 10 P.M. Pumping during the designated no-pump period results in a higher demand charge rate

PG&E's Peak Day Pricing (PDP) is an optional rate that offers businesses lower prices on summer (June 1 to September 30) electricity rates in exchange for higher prices during PDP event days. PDP event days are usually called on hot summer days. Nine to 15 event days can be called per year. During the events, an additional charge is added to energy use between 4 P.M. to 9 P.M. Participants shield their exposure to high prices during PDP events by shedding load during the peak price hours. For new program entrants, a bill protection option is available that prevents participants from paying more than they would have under their previous rate during the first year of PDP participation. Additional details on bill protection may be found at https://pgesupport.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/4414372633485-What-is-Reservation-Capacity

Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD) offers time-of-day rates to commercial, industrial, and agricultural customers to incentivize them to shift their demand away from peak periods. Peak periods take place during non-holiday weekdays from 4 P.M. to 9 P.M. during both summer (June through September) and winter (October through May).

Eversource offers numerous Time of Day rates to its Connecticut customers. Customers on these rates can save money be shifting their electricity consumption away from on-peak periods (Weekdays 12 - 8PM during Eastern Standard Time and 1 - 9 PM during Daylight Savings Times).

Other Rate Type.program_name: General Service and General Service Time-of-day EV Rate
Other Rate Type.hidden_program_name: General Service and General Service Time-of-day EV Rate
Other Rate Type.description: United Illuminating offers a General Service Time-of-Day Electric Vehicle (EV) Charging Station Rate. The rate is offered to customers with EV charging stations available for public and non-public use with direct current fast chargers (DCFCs). Also covered are installations of four or more networked Level 2 chargers that are enrolled in a managed charging program under the Workplace & Light-Duty Fleet Charging Program. Customers under this rate can save money by shifting EV charging away from peak times.

Hawaiian Electric (HECO) is offering new commercial EV rates through a five-year pilot program (2022-2027) that incentivizes charging during mid-day hours (when grid power from solar PV installations is plentiful). Three rates are offered through the pilot program, EV-J, EV-F, and EV-P, though EV-F is now closed for enrollments. For more information on these rates visit HECOs Commercial Facility Pilot rates page

Rocky Mountain Power offers its Time-of-Day rate plan for commercial and industrial customers of any size. Customers who can shift their usage to off-peak periods will see utility bill savings. On-peak periods are defined as 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. during winter (November – April) and 8 A.M. to 11 P.M. during summer (May – October), Monday through Friday, excluding holidays. Off-peak periods are all other times. For more information or to sign up, call (888) 221-7070.

Indiana Michigan Power (an AEP company) offers a General Service Plug-in Electric Vehicle tariff available to customers on Tariff GS who have averaged less than 4,500 kWh use per month in the previous 12 months. AEP offers two options under this rate, stand-alone PEV service and submetered PEV Time-of-day. The stand-alone PEV service option offers substantial savings to customers who charge their fleet during off-peak hours (11 P.M. – 6 A.M). The sub-metered PEV Time-of-Day option offers credits to customers' bills based on energy usage from charging PEVs during off-peak hours.

Alliant Energy offers Time of Day Pricing for Iowa business customers to take advantage of significantly lower electricity prices during off-peak hours. Off-peak hours are from 8 P.M. to 7 A.M. on weekdays, and all weekend. Usage is billed at a 60% discount to peak hours (7 A.M. to 8 P.M.). The program requires the installation of a smart meter that the customer pays for through a minimal monthly charge. In the case that the business does not realize a reduction in electricity costs, Alliant will remove the smart meter and reinstall a standard meter free of charge.

Evergy offers an Electric Vehicle Plan to EV owners. Customers can lower their vehicle charging costs substantially by shifting charging outside of peak hours (2-8 P.M.) and ideally into the program's "super off-peak" period of midnight to 6 A.M.

Entergy Louisiana offers a number of Time of Day Rates that provides utility bill savings for customers who can shift electricity use to off-peak hours, particularly during the summer. These rates are available for customers on the General Service (GS-G) who can contract for 5-4,000 kW, and Large Power Service (LPS-G) and High Load Factor Service (HLFS-G) schedule customers who can contrast for at least 2,500 kW of electrical service. On-peak summer hours are defined as 1-9 P.M., Monday – Friday, from May 15 to October 15. On-peak winter hours are defined as 6-10 A.M. and 6-10 P.M., Monday – Friday, from October 16 to May 14.

DTE offers an Electric Vehicle Rate to commercial customers for charging electric vehicles. Customers are able to save money by charging vehicles during on-peak hours when prices are higher. These on-peak hours occur from 9 A.M. to 11 P.M. Monday through Friday. This rate is currently closed to new customers as of May 2019.

Otter Tail Power Company's Deferred Load Rate helps customers save on heating and cooling costs by allowing thermal storage technologies (e.g., electric water heaters) to charge during off-peak hours and still provide service during peak periods when energy control is used. Loads may be controlled for up 14 hours per day.  Customers can also use this rate for certain heat pumps and level 2 EV chargers if they are connected to storage.

Otter Tail Power Company's Dual Fuel Rate allows customers to save on energy costs by switching from an electric heating system to a non-electric backup system during times of peak demand. There are two Dual Fuel Rate options, Large and Small, that are dependent on the electric service and metering installed at the facility. There are rate differences between winter and summer (June through September), as well as penalty charges.

Otter Tail Power Company's Fixed Time of Delivery Rates deliver electricity only between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M. There are separate rates offered for permanently connected deferred loads with self-contained metering, current transformer metering and primary current transformer metering served at primary voltage. Loads are typically thermal storage space heating or cooling or other approved loads. There are rate differences between winter and summer (June through September), as well as penalty charges for energy use outside of the fixed time of delivery window.

Xcel Energy offers a number of time of day rates, allowing General Service and Small General Service customers to save costs by shifting energy use away from periods of peak demand on the grid. On-peak hours run from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Monday through Friday, excluding holidays. Customers may choose the time-of-day rate for a trial period of three months and return to non-time-of-day service if desired with a charge of $25 to remove accompanying metering equipment.

Ameren's Large Primary Service and other commercial and industrial customer rates provide customers with an optional time-of-day adjustment that offers significant differences in on- and off-peak rates, particularly in the summer. Also, summer (June through September) demand charges (over $19/kW-mo. for Large Primary Service) are roughly two times those during winter months.
Dominion Energy offers a set of tariffs that reward commercial and industrial customers that can shift their load away from on-peak hours.

The General Service Thermal Energy Storage rate (GS-TES-7277) is available to customers in the Duke Energy Progress area who use thermal storage equipment to shift load away from on-peak periods in the summer from 12 to 8 P.M. (April through September) and winter from 6 A.M. to 1 P.M. (October through March). This rate is available to customers with a peak load of 4,000 kW or less.

Cass County Electric Cooperative offer special rates for EV charging, a time-of-day rate option and an off-peak option. Customers on the time-of-day rate can save money by shifting charging away from peak periods (Monday-Friday 6-9 AM and 5-8 PM). The off-peak rate options provides additional savings to customers who have additional off-peak loads in the home. On this rate, customers can only charge their vehicles between 12-5 PM and 11 PM - 7 AM (October-May) and 12 AM - 10 AM (June - September).

Cass County Electric Cooperative offers an incremental pricing plan, which is a demand response rate.  Customers who reduce their electric loads during times of peak demand on the grid are compensated with generous discounts on off-peak rates.

Other Rate Type.hidden_program_name: Optional Time-of-day General Electric Service Rates
Other Rate Type.description: Montana-Dakota offers the Optional Time-of-Day General Electric Service Rate and the Optional Time-of-Day Small General Electric Service Rate. These rates provide utility bill savings for shifting electricity usage to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months (June to September). On-peak hours are defined as 12 to 8 P.M., Monday through Friday.

Otter Tail Power Company's Deferred Load Rate helps customers save on heating and cooling costs by allowing thermal storage technologies (e.g., electric water heaters) to charge during off-peak hours and still provide service during peak periods when energy control is used. Loads may be controlled for up 14 hours per day.  Customers can also use this rate for certain heat pumps and level 2 EV chargers if they are connected to storage.

Otter Tail's Dual Fuel Rate program allows customers to save on energy costs by switching from an electric heating system to a non-electric backup system during times of peak demand. During peak conditions, the utility will automatically switch to the non-electric backup and when energy control is no longer needed, they return the system to normal operations. There are two Dual Fuel Rates, Large and Small, that are dependent on the electric service and metering installed at the facility.

Otter Tail Power Company's Fixed Time of Delivery Rates deliver electricity only between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M. There are separate rates offered for permanently connected deferred loads with self-contained metering, current transformer metering and primary current transformer metering served at primary voltage. Loads are typically thermal storage space heating or cooling or other approved loads. There are rate differences between winter and summer (June through September), as well as penalty charges for energy use outside of the fixed time of delivery window.

Otter Tail's Off-Peak Water Heating Rate (Rate 191) provide several money-saving options for customers with separately metered water heaters. Customers receive a credit on the monthly bill in exchange for permitting the utility to directly control their electric water heaters for up to 14 hours per day. Recovery periods are included whenever possible during longer control events. These programs may be combined with rebates for new electric water heaters. The Water Heating Credit for Standard General Service (Rate 192) allows farm and general commercial customers to receive a monthly bill credit when direct control on water heating appliances are installed. Similar to the Off-Peak Water Heating program, water heaters may be controlled up to 14 hours per day.

Xcel Energy offers General and Small General Time of Day Service rates.  These rates provide utility bill savings for shifting electricity usage to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months (June to September). On-peak hours are defined as 9 A.M. - 9 P.M., Monday through Friday excluding select holidays.

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company's Day Ahead Pricing Program lets businesses lower their energy costs by shifting use to the times of the day when rates are lower. OG&E notifies you of hourly rates the day before, so you can plan your day and save money. If demand reductions are not needed, standard pricing is use

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company's Flex Pricing program offers lower total electricity costs for facilities that are able to reduce usage during peak hours (2-7 P.M. weekdays, June 1 through September 30) or shift load to off-peak hours, when the rate is substantially lower.

Duquesne offers an Electric Vehicle Time-of Use Pilot program. This program is offered to small commercial and industrial customers with monthly metered demand less than 200 kW. Customers enrolled in this rate can save money by shifting the charging of their electric vehicles to off-peak times.

Other Rate Type.hidden_program_name: Optional Time-of-day General Electric Service Rate
Other Rate Type.description: Montana-Dakota offers the Optional Time-of-Day General Electric Service Rate and the Optional Time-of-Day Small General Electric Service Rate. These rates provide utility bill savings for shifting electricity usage to off-peak hours, particularly during summer months (June to September). On-peak hours are defined as 12 to 8 P.M., Monday through Friday.

Loads may be controlled for up 14 hours per day.  Customers can also use this rate for certain heat pumps and level 2 EV chargers if they are connected to storage.

There are two Dual Fuel Rates, Large and Small, that are dependent on the electric service and metering installed at the facility.

Loads are typically thermal storage space heating or cooling or other approved loads. There are rate differences between winter and summer (June through September), as well as penalty charges for energy use outside of the fixed time of delivery window.

The Water Heating Credit for Standard General Service (Rate 192) allows farm and general commercial customers to receive a monthly bill credit when direct control on water heating appliances are installed. Similar to the Off-Peak Water Heating program, water heaters may be controlled up to 14 hours per day.

Appalachian Power offers it's customers the General Service Time-of-Day Rate. Customers enrolled in this rate can save money by shifting to off-peak periods (9 PM - 6 AM weekdays, all hours of the day on weekends, and select holidays).

El Paso Electric also offers its Electric Vehicle Rate to customers with 120V or up to 480V chargers. The chargers must use a separate meter. The rate is split into summer (June-September) and non-summer (October-May) rates, where the summer period has both on-and off-peak pricing. There is also a year-round rate for super-off peak periods, which occur from 12 to 8 A.M. (MDT).

Entergy Texas offers numerous Time of Day Rates. Customers enrolling in these rates can save money by reducing energy use during peak periods. Summer on peak hours are from 1 - 9  PM Monday through Friday and Winter on peak hours are 6 -10 AM and 6-10 PM Monday through Friday.

The Load Management Standard Offer Program is available to commercial customers who can curtail at least 100 kW during peak demand periods in return for payments of $35 or $50 per kW (based on customer commitments). Participating customers will receive one-hour advanced notice prior to events. The program runs from June 1 through September 30, with all events on weekdays between 12 and 8 P.M. The maximum event duration is four hours. The program site will be open for registration mid February and applications are accepted from April 1 - May 10th. The application period for the 2024 program is currently closed. Check the Xcel website for the most up to date information on the 2025 enrollment period.

Rocky Mountain Power's Time of Day Plan offers utility cost savings for customers who can reduce their energy demand during peak periods (1 - 8 PM weekdays). This rate is available for customers on rate Schedules 1 and 3.

Other Rate Type.hidden_program_name: Intermediate General Service Time of Usage
Other Rate Type.description: Dominion Energy's Intermediate General Service Time of Usage (Schedule GS-2T) rate rewards commercial/industrial customers with peak loads below 500 kW for switching usage to off-peak periods (10 P.M. to 10 A.M., June through September; 10 P.M. to 7 A.M., October through May).

Rappahannock Electric Cooperative (REC) offers the Peak Time Rebate (Schedule PTR) to small general service customers who can reduce energy usage when the utility calls for Peak Time Events. REC provides peak time rebate credits to the customer based on the energy reduced during the peak periods. The customer will receive notification of a Peak Time Event at least two hours prior and usually before 12 P.M. on the day of the event.

Appalachian and Wheeling also offer the General Service Time-of-Day (GS-TOD) and Large General Service Time-of-Day (LGS-TOD) rates, which allow customers to reduce energy costs by shifting their energy demand away from on-peak hours (7 A.M. to 9 P.M, non-holiday weekdays). The GS-TOD rate is available to customers with a demand of 150 kW or less, and the LGS-TOD rate is available to customers with a demand greater than 150 kW but less than 1,000 kW.

Xcel Energy offers numerous time-of-day rates to commercial and industrial customers. These rates allow customers to save on energy cost by shifting load to off-peak periods. Rates in the summer (June through September) are higher than in the winter (October through May).
